Octamer	B-Biological_Molecule

Immunoglobulin	O

contain	O
two	O

.	O

phagocytes	O
are	O
exposed	O
to	O
fibrinous	O
provisional	O
matrix	O
throughout	O
migration	O
into	O
inflammatory	O
foci	O
,	O
so	O
this	O
study	O
was	O
undertaken	O
to	O
determine	O
whether	O
fibrinogen	O
triggers	O
activation	O
of	O
NF-kappa	B-Biological_Molecule
B	E-Biological_Molecule
transcription	O
factors	O
.	O

U937	O
cells	O
differentiated	O
with	O
PMA	O
in	O
nonadherent	O
culture	O
were	O
shown	O
to	O
express	O
two	O
fibrinogen-binding	O
integrins	O

,	O

to	O
a	O

,	O

.	O

Cells	O
stimulated	O
with	O
fibrinogen	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
10-100	O
microg/ml	O
)	O
/Mn2+	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
50	O
microM	O
)	O
for	O
2	O
h	O
were	O
examined	O
by	O
electrophoretic	O
mobility	O
shift	O
assay	O
.	O

NF-kappa	B-Biological_Molecule

activation	O
,	O
minimal	O
in	O
unstimulated	O
cells	O
,	O
was	O

by	O
fibrinogen	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

Fibrinogen	S-Biological_Molecule
also	O
caused	O
activation	O
of	O

,	O
but	O
not	O
SP1	S-Biological_Molecule
or	O
cAMP	B-Biological_Molecule
response	I-Biological_Molecule
element-binding	I-Biological_Molecule
protein	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
CREB	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
factors	O
.	O

Blocking	O
mAbs	O
against	O
CD18	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O

abrogated	O
fibrinogen	S-Biological_Molecule

activation	O
.	O

To	O

on	O

(	O

)	O

Cells	O
were	O

with	O
1	O

for	O

2	O

for	O
2	O

3.2-fold	O
,	O
or	O

with	O

and	O

5.7-fold	O

by	O

.	O

We	O
conclude	O
that	O
contact	O
with	O

proteins	O
may	O

to	O

.	O

and	O

.	O

OBJECTIVE	O
:	O
To	O
identify	O
and	O

(	O

)	O

expressed	O
in	O

of	O

(	O

)	O

.	O

METHODS	O
:	O
Peripheral	O
blood	O
monocytes	O
and	O
T	O
cells	O
were	O
prepared	O
from	O
patients	S-Species
with	O
SLE	O
(	O
n	O
=	O
6	O
)	O
and	O
healthy	O
donors	O
(	O
n	O
=	O
8	O
)	O
.	O

cells	O
were	O
separated	O
into	O
CD4	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
CD8	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

Some	O

and	O

were	O
stimulated	O
with	O

,	O

,	O
and	O
ionomycin	S-Chemical_Compound
.	O

Epstein-Barr	O

B	O
cell	O

(	O

=	O
7	O
)	O
and	O
B	O

(	O
n	O
=	O
2	O
)	O

from	O
patients	S-Species
with	O

and	O
a	O

individual	O
were	O
used	O
as	O
a	O

.	O

These	O
cells	O
were	O

for	O
ER	S-Biological_Molecule
mRNA	O
by	O
reverse	O
transcription	O
nested	O

chain	O
reaction	O
.	O

Amplified	O

by	O
standard	O
methods	O
.	O

RESULTS	O
:	O
In	O
all	O
cells	O
tested	O
,	O
ER	S-Biological_Molecule
mRNA	O
was	O
expressed	O
without	O
prior	O
in	O
vitro	O
stimulation	O
.	O

Partial	O
sequences	O
from	O
exons	O
1-8	O
were	O
nearly	O
identical	O
to	O
the	O
published	O
sequence	O
of	O
the	O
human	S-Species
ER	S-Biological_Molecule
mRNA	O
.	O

There	O
were	O
no	O
notable	O
differences	O
in	O
the	O
ER	S-Biological_Molecule
transcripts	O
between	O
patients	S-Species
and	O
healthy	O
controls	O
.	O

Variant	O
receptor	O
transcripts	O
lacking	O
exon	O
5	O
or	O
exon	O
7	O
,	O
which	O
encodes	O
the	O
hormone	O
binding	O
domain	O
,	O
were	O
identified	O
in	O
the	O
majority	O
of	O
the	O
cells	O
.	O

Precise	O
deletion	O
of	O
the	O
exons	O
suggests	O
that	O
they	O
are	O
alternatively	O
spliced	O
transcripts	O
.	O

Whether	O
the	O
detected	O
transcripts	O
are	O
translated	O
into	O
functional	O
receptor	O
proteins	O
remains	O
to	O
be	O
determined	O
.	O

In	O
vitro	O
stimulation	O
did	O
not	O
affect	O
ER	S-Biological_Molecule
mRNA	O
expression	O
.	O

The	O
presence	O
of	O
variants	O
did	O
not	O
correlate	O
with	O
disease	O
activity	O
or	O
medication	O
.	O

CONCLUSION	O
:	O
Monocytes	O
,	O
T	O
cells	O
,	O
and	O
B	O
cells	O
in	O
patients	S-Species
express	O
transcripts	O
of	O
the	O
normal	O
wild	O
type	O
ER	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
the	O
hormone	O
binding	O
domain	O
variants	O
in	O
vivo	O
.	O

DNA	O
damaging	O
agents	O
induce	O
expression	O
of	O
Fas	B-Biological_Molecule
ligand	E-Biological_Molecule
and	O
subsequent	O
apoptosis	O
in	O
T	O
lymphocytes	O
via	O
the	O
activation	O
of	O
NF-kappa	B-Biological_Molecule
B	E-Biological_Molecule
and	O
AP-1	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

Apoptosis	O
induced	O
by	O
DNA	O
damage	O
and	O
other	O
stresses	O
can	O
proceed	O
via	O
expression	O
of	O
Fas	B-Biological_Molecule
ligand	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
FasL	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
and	O
ligation	O
of	O
its	O
receptor	O
,	O
Fas	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
CD95	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
.	O

We	O
report	O
that	O
activation	O
of	O
the	O
two	O
transcription	O
factors	O
NF-kappa	B-Biological_Molecule
B	E-Biological_Molecule
and	O
AP-1	S-Biological_Molecule
is	O
crucially	O
involved	O
in	O
FasL	S-Biological_Molecule
expression	O
induced	O
by	O
etoposide	S-Chemical_Compound
,	O
teniposide	S-Chemical_Compound
,	O
and	O
UV	O
irradiation	O
.	O

A	O
nondegradable	O
mutant	O
of	O
I	O
kappa	O
B	O
blocked	O
both	O
FasL	S-Biological_Molecule
expression	O
and	O
apoptosis	O
induced	O
by	O
DNA	O
damage	O
but	O
not	O
Fas	S-Biological_Molecule
ligation	O
.	O

These	O
stimuli	O
also	O
induced	O
the	O
stress-activated	O
kinase	O
pathway	O
(	O
SAPK/JNK	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
,	O
which	O
was	O
required	O
for	O
the	O
maximal	O
induction	O
of	O
apoptosis	O
.	O

A	O
1.2	O
kb	O
FasL	S-Biological_Molecule
promoter	O
responded	O
to	O
DNA	O
damage	O
,	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
coexpression	O
with	O
p65	S-Biological_Molecule
Rel	O
or	O
Fos/Jun	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

Mutations	O
in	O
the	O
relevant	O
NF-kappa	B-Biological_Molecule
B	E-Biological_Molecule
and	O
AP-1	S-Biological_Molecule
binding	O
sites	O
eliminated	O
these	O
responses	O
.	O

Thus	O
,	O
activation	O
of	O
NF-kappa	B-Biological_Molecule
B	E-Biological_Molecule
and	O
AP-1	S-Biological_Molecule
contributes	O
to	O
stress-induced	O
apoptosis	O
via	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
FasL	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

A	O
small	O
,	O
nonpeptidyl	O
mimic	O
of	O
granulocyte-colony-stimulating	B-Biological_Molecule
factor	E-Biological_Molecule
[	O
see	O
commetns	O
]	O

A	O
nonpeptidyl	O
small	O
molecule	O
SB	B-Chemical_Compound
247464	O
,	O
capable	O
of	O
activating	B-Biological_Molecule
granulocyte-colony-stimulating	I-Biological_Molecule

(	O

)	O
signal	O
transduction	O
pathways	O

was	O
identified	O
in	O
a	O
high-throughput	O
assay	O
in	O
cultured	O
cells	O
.	O

Like	O
G-CSF	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
SB	B-Biological_Molecule
247464	O
induced	O
tyrosine	S-Chemical_Compound

of	O
multiple	O
signaling	O

and	O

murine	S-Species

to	O

in	O

.	O

It	O

in	O
mice	S-Species
.	O

of	O

was	O

that	O
a	O

can	O

a	O

that	O

Minimal	O

with	O

Eight	O

of	O

.	O

Mycobacterium	B-Species
tuberculosis	O
mannose-capped	I-Species
lipoarabinomannan	S-Biological_Molecule
can	O
induce	O
NF-kappaB	S-Biological_Molecule
-dependent	O
activation	O
of	O
human	O
immunodeficiency	O
virus	O
type	O
1	O
long	O
terminal	O
repeat	O
in	O
T	O
cells	O
.	O

Tuberculosis	O
has	O
emerged	O
as	O
an	O
epidemic	O
,	O
extended	O
by	O
the	O
large	O
number	O
of	O
individuals	S-Species
infected	O
with	O
human	O
immunodeficiency	O
virus	O
type	O
1	O
(	O
HIV-1	S-Species
)	O
.	O

The	O
major	O
goal	O
of	O
this	O
study	O
was	O
to	O
determine	O
whether	O
the	O
mycobacterial	O
cell	O
wall	O
component	O
mannose-capped	O
lipoarabinomannan	O
(	O
ManLAM	O
)	O
of	O
Mycobacterium	B-Species
tuberculosis	E-Species
(	O
M.	B-Species
tuberculosis	E-Species

Arrest	O
of	O
B	O

of	O

Despite	O

(	O

of	O

.	O

A	O

acid	I-Chemical_Compound

:	O

Epidemiology	O
and	O
pathogenesis	O
of	O
AIDS-related	O
lymphomas	O
.	O

Among	O
patients	S-Species
with	O
congenital	O
and	O
acquired	O
immunodeficiencies	O
,	O
non-Hodgkin	O
's	O
lymphoma	O
(	O
NHLs	O
)	O
are	O
the	O
most	O
common	O
tumors	O
of	O
the	O
immune	O
system	O
.	O

In	O
the	O
setting	O
of	O
human	O
immunodeficiency	O
virus	O
(	O
HIV	S-Species
)	O
infection	O

as	O
10	O
%	O
to	O
20	O
%	O
of	O
people	S-Species
ultimately	O
developed	O
NHLs	O
.	O

These	O
tumors	O
are	O
clinically	O
aggressive	O
,	O
frequently	O
involve	O
extranodal	O
sites	O
,	O
and	O
often	O
exhibit	O
unique	O
features	O
that	O
distinguish	O
them	O
from	O
NHL	S-Biological_Molecule
arising	O
in	O
individuals	S-Species
with	O
other	O
forms	O
of	O
immunosuppression	O
.	O

Important	O
in	O
the	O
development	O
of	O
HIV-associated	O
NHL	S-Biological_Molecule
are	O
cytokines	O
and	O
other	O
factors	O
that	O
induce	O
B-cell	O
proliferation	O
and	O
increase	O
the	O
likelihood	O
of	O
mutations	O
of	O
c-myc	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
bcl-6	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
and	O
other	O

.	O

T-cell	B-Biological_Molecule

Mutation	O

(	O

)	O
genes	O

to	O

of	O

genes	O
.	O

Non-Hodgkin	O

[	O

no	O

of	O

tissue	O
origin	O

of	O
MIP-1	B-Biological_Molecule
alpha	E-Biological_Molecule
nuclear	O
protein	E-Biological_Molecule
.	O

A	O
family	O
of	O
hematopoietic	O
specific	O
transcription	O
factors	O
,	O
MIP-1	B-Biological_Molecule

(	O

has	O

They	O

in	O

One	O

:	O

:	O

:	O

CONCLUSIONS	O
:	O

of	O

type	O
1	O
diabetes	O

Antigen	B-Biological_Molecule

The	O

encodes	O
a	O

finger	O

repressor	O

in	O

center	O
(	O

)	O

and	O

for	O

.	O

of	O

expression	O

that	O

(	O

targets	O

for	O

that	O

.	O

pathway	O
may	O
be	O
crucial	O
for	O
the	O
control	O
of	O
B-cell	O
differentiation	O
and	O
antibody	O
response	O
and	O
has	O
implications	O
for	O

The	O

is	O

BACKGROUND	O
:	O
Antigen-receptor	O
interactions	O
on	O
lymphocytes	O
result	O
in	O
local	O
clustering	O
of	O
actin	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
receptors	O
and	O
signaling	O
molecules	O
into	O
an	O
asymmetric	O
membrane	O
structure	O
termed	O
a	O
cap	O
.	O

Although	O
actin	S-Biological_Molecule
polymerization	O
is	O
known	O
to	O
be	O
required	O
,	O
the	O
mechanisms	O
underlying	O
cap	O
formation	O
are	O
unclear	O
.	O

We	O
have	O
studied	O
the	O
events	O
underlying	O
cap	O
formation	O
using	O
mice	S-Species
bearing	O
a	O
null	O
mutation	O
in	O
vav	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
vav	S-Biological_Molecule
-/-	O
)	O
,	O
a	O
gene	O
that	O
encodes	O
a	O
guanine-nucleotide	S-Chemical_Compound
exchange	O
factor	O
for	O
the	O
GTPase	O
Rac	O
.	O

RESULTS	O
:	O
Lymphocytes	O
from	O
vav	S-Biological_Molecule
-/-	O
mice	O
failed	O
to	O
form	O
T-cell	O
receptor	O
caps	O
following	O
activation	O
and	O
had	O
a	O
defective	O
actin	O
cytoskeleton	O
.	O

The	O
vav-/-	O
T	O
cells	O
were	O
deficient	O
in	O
interleukin-2	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
IL-2	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
production	O
and	O
proliferation	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
peak	O
of	O
Ca2+	S-Biological_Molecule
mobilization	O
was	O
reduced	O
although	O
of	O
normal	O
duration	O
.	O

Activation	O
of	O
Jun	O
N-terminal	O
kinase	O
or	O
stress-activated	O
kinase	O
(	O
JNK	O
or	O
SAPK	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
and	O
mitogen-activated	O
protein	O
kinase	O
(	O
MAPK	O
)	O
and	O
the	O
induction	O
of	O
the	O
transcription	O
factor	O
NF-ATc1	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
egr-1	S-Biological_Molecule
genes	O
was	O
normal	O
.	O

Despite	O
the	O
reduced	O
Ca2+	S-Biological_Molecule
mobilization	O
,	O
translocation	O
of	O
cytoplasmic	O
NF-ATc	S-Biological_Molecule
to	O
the	O
nucleus	O
was	O
normal	O
,	O
reflecting	O
that	O
the	O
lower	O
levels	O
of	O
Ca2+	S-Biological_Molecule
in	O
vav-/-	O
cells	O
were	O
still	O
sufficient	O
to	O
activate	O
calcineurin	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

Treatment	O
of	O
lymphocytes	O
with	O
cytochalasin	B-Chemical_Compound
D	E-Chemical_Compound
,	O
which	O
blocks	O
actin	S-Biological_Molecule
polymerization	O

inhibited	O
cap	O
formation	O
and	O
produced	O
defects	O
in	O
signaling	O
and	O
IL-2	S-Biological_Molecule
transcriptional	O
induction	O
in	O
response	O
to	O
antigen-receptor	O
signaling	O
that	O
were	O
nearly	O
identical	O
to	O
those	O
seen	O
in	O
vav-/-	O
cells	O
.	O

In	O
transfection	O
studies	O
,	O
either	O
constitutively	O
active	O
Vav	S-Biological_Molecule
or	O
Rac	S-Biological_Molecule
could	O
complement	O
constitutively	O
active	O
calcineurin	S-Biological_Molecule
to	O
activate	O
NF-AT-dependent	O
transcription	O
.	O

CONCLUSIONS	O
:	O
These	O
results	O
indicate	O
that	O
Vav	S-Biological_Molecule
is	O
required	O
for	O
cap	O
formation	O
in	O
lymphocytes	O
.	O

Furthermore	O
,	O
the	O
correlation	O
between	O
cap	O
formation	O

IL-2	S-Biological_Molecule
production	O
and	O
proliferation	O
supports	O
the	O
hypothesis	O
that	O
an	O
actin-dependent	O
pathway	O
is	O
a	O
source	O
of	O
specialized	O
growth	O
regulatory	O
signals	O
.	O

NF-kappaB	S-Biological_Molecule
protects	O

from	O

.	O

HIV-1	S-Species
infection	O
of	O
primary	O

cells	O

cell	O

results	O
in	O

(	O

)	O

(	O

)	O
cells	O

signaling	O
.	O

TNFalpha	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O

caused	O

and	O

of	O

-induced	O

of	O

that	O

protects	O
cells	O
from	O

Transcription	O
factors	O
that	O
regulate	O
monocyte	O
/	O
macrophage	O
differentiation	O
.	O

Although	O
all	O
the	O
cells	O
in	O
an	O

same	O

information	O

in	O
the	O
cell	O

from	O

of	O

genes	O
.	O

During	O

,	O
external	O
differentiating	O
signals	O
regulate	O

expression	O

of	O

expression	O

of	O

and	O

.	O

In	O
particular	O
,	O
the	O
transcription	O
factor	O
PU.1	S-Biological_Molecule
has	O
a	O

in	O
this	O

.	O

of	O
macrophage	O

factor	O

is	O
sufficient	O
to	O
program	O
T	O
cell	O

via	O
a	O

--	O
dependent	O
pathway	O
.	O

T	O
lymphocytes	O
circulate	O
in	O
a	O

encounter	O
cognate	O

to	O

that	O

BACKGROUND/AIMS	S-Chemical_Compound
:	O

and	O

production	O
are	O

in	O

Lymph	O

Biomechanical	O
strain	O
induces	O
class	O

human	S-Species

BACKGROUND	O
:	O

:	O
:	O

.	O

The	O
role	O
of	O
Epstein-Barr	B-Species
virus	E-Species
in	O
neoplastic	O
transformation	O
.	O

on	O

(	O

(	I-Biological_Molecule

a	O
gluten-sensitive	O
Th1-mediated	O
enteropathy	O
,	O
characterized	O
by	O
villous	O
atrophy	O
and	O
crypt	O
cell	O
hyperplasia	O
.	O

Previous	O
studies	O
from	O
this	O
laboratory	O
have	O
shown	O
that	O
T	O
cell	O
activation	O
in	O
explant	O
cultures	O
of	O
human	S-Species
fetal	O
gut	O
can	O
also	O
result	O
in	O
villous	O
atrophy	O
and	O
crypt	O
cell	O
hyperplasia	O
.	O

We	O
have	O
,	O
therefore	O
,	O
examined	O
changes	O
that	O
take	O
place	O
in	O
explant	O
cultures	O
of	O
human	S-Species
fetal	O
gut	O
after	O
activation	O
of	O
T	O
cells	O
with	O
anti-CD3	O
and/or	O
IFN-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

We	O
show	O
that	O
activation	O
of	O
T	O
cells	O
with	O
anti-CD3	O
alone	O
elicits	O
a	O
small	O
IFN-gamma	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
TNF-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
response	O
with	O
no	O
tissue	O
injury	O
.	O

Similarly	O
,	O
no	O
changes	O
are	O
seen	O
in	O
explants	O
cultured	O
with	O
IFN-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
alone	O
.	O

However	O
,	O
addition	O
of	O
IFN-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
with	O
anti-CD3	S-Biological_Molecule
results	O
in	O
enhanced	O
Th1	O
response	O
and	O
crypt	O
cell	O
hyperplasia	O
.	O

This	O
is	O
associated	O
with	O
enhanced	O
phosphorylation	O
of	O
STAT1	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
STAT3	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
and	O
Fyn	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
a	O
Src	S-Biological_Molecule
homology	O
tyrosine	S-Chemical_Compound
kinase	O
,	O
which	O
interacts	O
with	O
both	O
TCR	O
and	O
IFN-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
signal	O
components	O
.	O

Together	O
these	O
data	O
indicate	O
that	O
IFN-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
can	O
facilitate	O
activation	O
of	O
Th1-reactive	O
cells	O
in	O
the	O
gut	O
and	O
drive	O
immunopathology	O
.	O

Suppression	O
of	O
tumor	B-Biological_Molecule
necrosis	I-Biological_Molecule
factor	I-Biological_Molecule
alpha	E-Biological_Molecule
production	O
by	O
cAMP	O
in	O
human	O
monocytes	O
:	O
dissociation	O
with	O
mRNA	O
level	O
and	O
independent	O
of	O
interleukin-10	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

BACKGROUND	O
:	O
Elevation	O
of	O
cellular	O
cAMP	S-Chemical_Compound
inhibits	O
lipopolysaccharide	S-Chemical_Compound
(	O
LPS	S-Chemical_Compound
)	O
-stimulated	O
tumor	B-Biological_Molecule
necrosis	I-Biological_Molecule
factor	I-Biological_Molecule
alpha	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
TNF-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
production	O
and	O
increases	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
interleukin	B-Biological_Molecule
(	I-Biological_Molecule
IL	I-Biological_Molecule
)	I-Biological_Molecule
-10	E-Biological_Molecule
in	O
mononuclear	O
cells	O
.	O

TNF-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
gene	O
expression	O
obligates	O
activation	O
of	O
the	O
transcription	O
factor	O
nuclear	O
factor	O
kappaB	O
(	O
NF-kappaB	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
.	O

Exogenous	O
IL-10	S-Biological_Molecule
inhibits	O
NF-kappaB	S-Biological_Molecule
in	O
monocytes	O
and	O
thus	O
attenuates	O
TNF-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
production	O
.	O

We	O
examined	O
the	O
role	O
of	O
endogenous	O
IL-10	S-Biological_Molecule
in	O
the	O
regulation	O
of	O
NF-kappaB	O
activation	O
and	O
TNF-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
production	O
in	O
human	S-Species
monocytes	O
by	O
cAMP	S-Chemical_Compound
.	O

METHODS	O
:	O
Human	S-Species
monocytes	O
were	O
stimulated	O
with	O
Escherichia	B-Species
coli	E-Species
LPS	S-Chemical_Compound
(	O
100	O
ng/ml	O
)	O
with	O
and	O
without	O
forskolin	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
FSK	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
50	O
microM	O
)	O
or	O
dibutyryl	O
cyclic	O

(	O
dbcAMP	O
,	O
100	O
microM	O
)	O
.	O

Cytokine	O
(	O
TNF-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
IL-10	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
release	O
was	O
measured	O
by	O
immunoassay	O
.	O

TNF-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
mRNA	O
was	O
measured	O
by	O
reverse	O
transcription	O
polymerase	O
chain	O
reaction	O
,	O
and	O

was	O
assessed	O
by	O
gel	O

shift	O
assay	O
.	O

RESULTS	O
:	O
cAMP-elevating	O
agents	O
inhibited	O
LPS-stimulated	O
TNF-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
release	O
(	O
0.77	O
+/-	O
0.13	O
ng/10	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
6	O
)	O
cells	O
in	O

+	O
dbcAMP	O
and	O
0.68	O
+/-	O
0.19	O
ng/10	O
(	O
6	O
)	O
cells	O
in	O
LPS	S-Chemical_Compound
+	O
FSK	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
both	O
P	O
<	O
0.05	O
vs	O
1.61	O
+/-	O
0.34	O
ng/10	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
6	O
)	O
cells	O
in	O

alone	O
)	O
.	O

Conversely	O

(	O

(	O

(	O

)	O
cells	O
in	O

+	O

,	O
both	O

<	O
0.05	O
vs	O
53.3	O
+/-	O

(	O

Neither	O

CONCLUSION	O
:	O
The	O
results	O
indicate	O
that	O
cAMP	S-Chemical_Compound
inhibits	O
LPS-stimulated	O
TNF-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
production	O
through	O
a	O
posttranscriptional	O
mechanism	O
that	O
is	O
independent	O
of	O
endogenous	O
IL-10	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

Copyright	O
2001	O
Academic	O
Press	O
.	O

Activation	O
of	O
the	O
p21	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
CIP1/WAF1	S-Biological_Molecule
)	E-Biological_Molecule
promoter	O
by	O
bone	O
morphogenetic	O
protein-2	S-Biological_Molecule
in	O
mouse	S-Species
B	O
lineage	O
cells	O
.	O

BMPs	O
exert	O
a	O
negative	O
growth	O
effect	O
on	O
various	O
types	O
of	O
cells	O
.	O

We	O
have	O
previously	O
reported	O
that	O
BMP-2	S-Biological_Molecule
inhibited	O
the	O
growth	O
of	O
HS-72	O
mouse	S-Species
hybridoma	O
cells	O
by	O
inducing	O
p21	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
CIP1/WAF1	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
expression	O
.	O

In	O
the	O
present	O
study	O
,	O
we	O
demonstrated	O
that	O
BMP-2	S-Biological_Molecule
activated	O
the	O
mouse	O
p21	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
CIP1/WAF1	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
promoter	O
in	O
HS-72	O
cells	O
,	O
and	O
that	O
a	O
29-base	O
pair	O
(	O
b	O
)	O
region	O
of	O
the	O
promoter	O
(	O
-1928/-1900	S-Biological_Molecule
relative	O
to	O
the	O
TATA	O
box	O
)	O
,	O
conserved	O
between	O
mice	S-Species
and	O
humans	S-Species
,	O
was	O
responsive	O
to	O
BMP-2	S-Biological_Molecule
as	O
well	O
as	O
expression	O
of	O
Smad1	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
Smad4	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
and	O
constitutively	O
active	O
mutants	O
of	O
BMP	B-Biological_Molecule
type	I-Biological_Molecule
I	E-Biological_Molecule
receptors	O
.	O

Furthermore	O
,	O
an	O
oligonucleotide	O
containing	O
the	O
29-b	S-Chemical_Compound
region	O
was	O
found	O
to	O
be	O
associated	O
with	O
Smad4	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
phosphorylated	O
Smad1	S-Biological_Molecule
in	O
the	O
nuclear	O
extract	O
of	O
BMP-2	S-Biological_Molecule
-stimulated	O
HS-72	O
cells	O
.	O

These	O
results	O
suggested	O
that	O
BMP-2	S-Biological_Molecule
might	O
activate	O
p21	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
CIP1/WAF1	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
transcription	O
by	O
inducing	O
a	O
binding	O
of	O
Smad4	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
Smad1	S-Biological_Molecule
to	O
the	O
29-b	O
region	O
in	O
HS-72	O
cells	O
.	O

Dendritic	O
cell	O
development	O
from	O
common	O
myeloid	O
progenitors	O
.	O

Dendritic	O
cells	O
(	O
DCs	O
)	O
are	O
professional	O
antigen-presenting	O
cells	O
which	O
both	O
initiate	O
adaptive	O
immune	O
responses	O
and	O
control	O
tolerance	O
to	O
self-antigens	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

It	O
has	O
been	O
suggested	O
that	O
these	O
different	O
effects	O
on	O
responder	O
cells	O
depend	O
on	O
subsets	O
of	O
DCs	O
arising	O
from	O
either	O
myeloid	O
or	O
lymphoid	O
hematopoietic	O
origins	O
.	O

In	O
this	O
model	O
,	O
CD8	S-Biological_Molecule
alpha+	O
Mac-1-	S-Biological_Molecule
DCs	O
are	O
supposed	O
to	O
be	O
of	O
lymphoid	O
while	O
CD8	S-Biological_Molecule
alpha-	O
Mac-1+	S-Biological_Molecule
DCs	O
are	O
supposed	O
to	O
be	O
of	O
myeloid	O
origin	O
.	O

Here	O
we	O
summarize	O
our	O
findings	O
that	O
both	O
CD8	S-Biological_Molecule
alpha+	O
and	O
CD8	S-Biological_Molecule
alpha-	O
DCs	O
can	O
arise	O
from	O
clonogenic	O
common	O
myeloid	O
progenitors	O
(	O
CMPs	O
)	O
in	O
both	O
thymus	O
and	O
spleen	O
.	O

Therefore	O
CD8	B-Biological_Molecule
alpha	E-Biological_Molecule
expression	O
DCs	O
does	O
not	O
indicate	O
a	O
lymphoid	O
origin	O
and	O
differences	O
among	O
CD8	S-Biological_Molecule
alpha+	O
and	O
CD8	S-Biological_Molecule
alpha-	O
DCs	O
might	O
rather	O
reflect	O
maturation	O
status	O
than	O
ontogeny	O
.	O

On	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
transplantation	O
studies	O
,	O
it	O
seems	O
likely	O
that	O
most	O
of	O
the	O
DCs	O
in	O
secondary	O
lymphoid	O
organs	O
and	O
a	O
substantial	O
fraction	O
of	O
thymic	O
DCs	O
are	O
myeloid-derived	O
.	O

Macrophage	O
stimulation	O
with	O
Murabutide	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
an	O
HIV-suppressive	S-Biological_Molecule
muramyl	O
peptide	O
derivative	O
,	O
selectively	O
activates	O
extracellular	B-Biological_Molecule
signal-regulated	I-Biological_Molecule
kinases	I-Biological_Molecule
1	E-Biological_Molecule
and	O
2	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
C/EBPbeta	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
STAT1	S-Biological_Molecule
:	O
role	O
of	O
CD14	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
Toll-like	B-Biological_Molecule
receptors	I-Biological_Molecule
2	E-Biological_Molecule
and	O
4	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

The	O
smallest	O
unit	O
of	O
bacterial	O
peptidoglycans	S-Chemical_Compound
known	O
to	O
be	O
endowed	O
with	O
biological	O
activities	O
is	O
muramyl	B-Chemical_Compound
dipeptide	E-Chemical_Compound
(	O
MDP	S-Chemical_Compound
)	O
.	O

A	O
clinically	O
acceptable	O
synthetic	O
derivative	O
of	O
MDP	O
,	O
namely	O
murabutide	S-Chemical_Compound
(	O
MB	O
)	O
,	O
has	O
been	O
found	O
to	O
present	O
interesting	O
pharmacological	O
properties	O
and	O
to	O
suppress	O
HIV-1	S-Species
replication	O
in	O
monocyte-derived	O
macrophages	O
(	O
MDM	O
)	O
.	O

We	O
have	O
addressed	O
the	O
signaling	O
events	O
activated	O
in	O
MDM	O
following	O
stimulation	O
with	O
either	O
MB	S-Biological_Molecule
or	O
the	O
potent	O
immunostimulant	O
LPS	S-Chemical_Compound
.	O

We	O
also	O
examined	O
whether	O
signaling	O

the	O
use	O
of	O
cell	O
surface	O
receptors	O
,	O
including	O
CD14	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
Toll-like	B-Biological_Molecule
receptor	I-Biological_Molecule
2	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
TLR2	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
or	O
TLR4	S-Biological_Molecule
that	O
are	O
known	O
to	O
be	O

for	O
other	O

cell	O

components	O
.	O

We	O
demonstrate	O
that	O
,	O
unlike	O

,	O
the	O
safe	O

kinases	O
(	O

)	O

,	O
in	O

of	O
detectable	O

N-terminal	O
kinase	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O

)	O
or	O
p38	O

kinase	O
activation	O
.	O

Furthermore	O
,	O
STAT1	S-Biological_Molecule
activation	O
but	O
weak	O
or	O
no	O

of	O
STAT3	S-Biological_Molecule
or	O
STAT5	S-Biological_Molecule
respectively	O
,	O
could	O
be	O

in	O

.	O

Using	O
MonoMac6	O
cells	O
,	O

observed	O
high	O

and	O

weaker	O

by	O
MB	O
.	O

Moreover	O
,	O
the	O

form	O
of	O

,	O
known	O
to	O
repress	O

from	O

cells	O
.	O

Surprisingly	O
,	O
neither	O

nor	O

were	O

to	O
transduce	O

via	O

and	O
TLR2	S-Biological_Molecule
or	O

.	O

These	O
findings	O
present	O
major	O
differences	O
in	O
the	O
early	O
cell	O

process	O
between	O

and	O
muramyl	O
peptides	O

strongly	O
argue	O
for	O

of	O

other	O

TLR2	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O

in	O

signaling	O
events	O
induced	O
by	O
defined	O
subunits	O
of	O
bacterial	O
peptidoglycans	O
.	O

Nuclear	B-Biological_Molecule
peroxisome	B-Biological_Molecule
proliferator-activated	I-Biological_Molecule
receptors	I-Biological_Molecule
alpha	E-Biological_Molecule
and	O
gamma	S-Biological_Molecule
have	O
opposing	O
effects	O
on	O
monocyte	O
chemotaxis	O
in	O
endometriosis	O
.	O

The	O
peroxisome	B-Biological_Molecule
proliferator-activated	I-Biological_Molecule
receptors	I-Biological_Molecule
(	I-Biological_Molecule
PPARs	I-Biological_Molecule
)	I-Biological_Molecule
alpha	E-Biological_Molecule
and	O
gamma	S-Biological_Molecule
are	O
nuclear	O
receptors	O
that	O
play	O
important	O
roles	O
in	O
inflammatory	O
diseases	O
like	O
ulcerative	O
colitis	O
and	O
arthritis	O
.	O

In	O
this	O
study	O
,	O
we	O
examined	O
the	O
possible	O
role	O
of	O
PPARs	S-Biological_Molecule
in	O
macrophage	O
attraction	O
into	O
the	O
peritoneal	O
cavity	O
of	O
patients	S-Species
with	O
endometriosis	O
.	O

We	O
identified	O
PPAR-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
-gamma	S-Biological_Molecule
messenger	O
RNA	O
by	O
RT-PCR	O
and	O
protein	O
by	O
immunoblotting	O
of	O
lysates	O
of	O
peritoneal	O
macrophages	O
and	O
monocytic	O
U937	O
cells	O
.	O

Using	O
immunocytochemistry	O
,	O
we	O
localized	O
PPAR-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
-gamma	S-Biological_Molecule
within	O
the	O
nuclei	O
of	O
both	O
cell	O
types	O
.	O

Monocyte	O

Maturation	O
of	O
human	S-Species
dendritic	O
cells	O
as	O
sulfasalazine	S-Chemical_Compound
target	O
.	O

AIM	O
:	O
Sulfasalazine	S-Chemical_Compound
,	O
a	O
nonsteroidal	O
anti-inflammatory	O
drug	O
,	O
is	O
effective	O
in	O
treating	O
some	O
autoimmune	O
diseases	O
,	O
but	O
its	O
mechanism	O
of	O
action	O
is	O
unclear	O
.	O

To	O
determine	O
whether	O
dendritic	O
cells	O
could	O
be	O
a	O
possible	O
target	O
of	O
the	O
drug	O
,	O
we	O
studied	O
the	O
effects	O
of	O
sulfasalazine	S-Chemical_Compound
and	O
its	O
metabolites	O
,	O
aminosalicylate	S-Chemical_Compound
and	O
sulfapyridine	S-Chemical_Compound
,	O
on	O
in	O
vitro	O
maturation	O
(	O
terminal	O
differentiation	O
)	O
of	O
human	S-Species
myeloid	O
dendritic	O
cells	O
.	O

METHODS	O
:	O
We	O
prepared	O
immature	O
dendritic	O
cells	O
by	O

cells	O
in	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
granulocyte-	B-Biological_Molecule
macrophage	I-Biological_Molecule
colony-stimulating	I-Biological_Molecule
factor	E-Biological_Molecule
and	O
interleukin	B-Biological_Molecule
(	I-Biological_Molecule
IL	I-Biological_Molecule
)	I-Biological_Molecule
-4	E-Biological_Molecule
.	O

The	O
cells	O
were	O
matured	O
by	O
addition	O
of	O
tumor	B-Biological_Molecule
necrosis	I-Biological_Molecule
factor	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
TNF	O
)	O

,	O

beta	E-Biological_Molecule
,	O
and	O
prostaglandin	B-Chemical_Compound

in	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
sulfasalazine	S-Chemical_Compound
or	O
its	O
metabolites	O
--	O
aminosalicylate	S-Chemical_Compound
and	O
sulfapyridine	S-Chemical_Compound
,	O
or	O
their	O
combinations	O

We	O

the	O
effect	O
of	O

on	O
the	O

,	O

subunit	E-Biological_Molecule
secretion	O

and	O
activation	O
of	O
nuclear	O
transcription	I-Biological_Molecule
factor	O
(	O
NF	O
)	O
-kappa	B-Biological_Molecule
B	E-Biological_Molecule
.	O

RESULTS	O
:	O
Dendritic	O
cells	O
treated	O
with	O
sulfasalazine	S-Chemical_Compound
(	O
1.25	O
micromol/L	O
or	O
2.5	O
micromol/L	O
)	O
could	O
not	O
stimulate	O
T	O
cells	O
(	O
p	O
<	O
0.028	O
,	O
two-sided	O
paired	O
t-test	O
)	O
.	O

In	O
distinction	O
to	O
drug-free	O
maturing	O
dendritic	O
cells	O
,	O
2.5	O
micromol/L	O
sulfasalazine	O
upregulated	O
the	O
levels	O
of	O
CD14	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
CD68	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
downregulated	O
the	O
levels	O
of	O
CD40	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
CD80	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
and	O
CD83	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
for	O
all	O
CD	O
markers	O
,	O
p	O
<	O
0.03	O
for	O
difference	O
between	O
measurements	O
in	O
the	O
absence	O
and	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
sulfasalazine	O
)	O
.	O

From	O
concentration-dependent	O
changes	O
in	O
CD83	S-Biological_Molecule
expression	O
,	O
we	O
found	O
an	O
apparent	O
ID50	S-Biological_Molecule
>	O
>	O
1.5	O
micromol/L	O
sulfasalazine	O
.	O

The	O
apparent	O
ID50	S-Biological_Molecule
value	O
for	O
aminosalicylate-inhibited	O
maturation	O
was	O
4	O
micromol/L	O
.	O

Sulfapyridine	S-Chemical_Compound
had	O
no	O
effect	O
.	O

At	O
1.25	O
micromol/L	O
,	O
sulfasalazine	S-Chemical_Compound
largely	O
inhibited	O

in	O
dendritic	O
cells	O
.	O

CONCLUSION	O
:	O
Maturing	O
human	S-Species
dendritic	O
cells	O
are	O
hundred-fold	O
more	O
sensitive	O
to	O
sulfasalazine	O
than	O
T	O
cells	O
and	O
NK	O
cells	O
and	O
the	O
most	O
sensitive	O
human	S-Species
cells	O
described	O
so	O
far	O
.	O

Thus	O
,	O
dendritic	O
cell	O
maturation	O
is	O
an	O
important	O
target	O
of	O
sulfasalazine	S-Chemical_Compound
.	O

Because	O
of	O
the	O
role	O
of	O
dendritic	O
cells	O
in	O
(	O
auto	O
)	O
immunity	O
,	O
inhibition	O
of	O
their	O
maturation	O
might	O
provide	O
a	O
target	O
for	O
further	O
optimization	O
of	O
sulfasalazine	S-Chemical_Compound
therapy	O
.	O

Defective	O
function	O
of	O
the	O
proteasome	O
in	O
autoimmunity	O
:	O
involvement	O
of	O
impaired	O
NF-kappaB	S-Biological_Molecule
activation	O
.	O

Type	O
1	O
diabetes	O
(	O
also	O
known	O
as	O
insulin-dependent	O
diabetes	O
mellitus	O
or	O
juvenile-onset	O
diabetes	O
)	O
is	O
usually	O
caused	O
by	O
T	O
cell-mediated	O
autoimmunity	O
,	O
with	O
a	O
prediabetic	O
state	O
characterized	O
by	O
the	O
production	O
of	O
autoantibodies	O
specific	O
for	O
proteins	O
expressed	O
by	O
pancreatic	O
beta	O
cells	O
.	O

The	O
nonobese	O
patient	O
with	O
diabetes	O
(	O
NOD	O
)	O
mouse	S-Species
is	O
a	O
spontaneous	O
model	O
of	O
type	O
1	O
diabetes	O
with	O
a	O
strong	O
genetic	O
component	O
that	O
maps	O
to	O
the	O
major	O
histocompatibility	O
complex	O
(	O
MHC	O
)	O
region	O
of	O
the	O
genome	O
.	O

A	O
specific	O
proteasome	O
defect	O
has	O
been	O
identified	O
in	O
NOD	O
mouse	S-Species
in	O
select	O
lymphocytic	O
and	O
monocytic	O
lineages	O
that	O
results	O
from	O
down-regulation	O
of	O
expression	O
of	O
the	O
proteasome	O
subunit	O
LMP2	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
which	O
is	O
encoded	O
by	O
a	O
gene	O
in	O
the	O
MHC	O
genomic	O
region	O
.	O

This	O
defect	O
prevents	O
the	O
proteolytic	O
processing	O
required	O
for	O
the	O
production	O
and	O
activation	O
of	O
the	O
transcription	O
factor	O
nuclear	O
factor-kappaB	O
(	O
NF-kappaB	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
,	O
which	O
plays	O
important	O
roles	O
in	O
immune	O
and	O
inflammatory	O
responses	O
,	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
increases	O
the	O
susceptibility	O
of	O
the	O
affected	O
cells	O
to	O
apoptosis	O
induced	O
by	O
tumor	O
necrosis	O
factor-alpha	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
TNF-alpha	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
novel	O
role	O
of	O
the	O
proteasome	O
in	O
dysfunction	O
in	O
autoimmunity	O
is	O
presented	O
and	O
documented	O
to	O
be	O
both	O
tissue	O
and	O
developmental	O
stage	O
specific	O
.	O

We	O
propose	O
a	O
role	O
of	O
the	O
proteasome	O
as	O
a	O
step	O
in	O
disease	O
pathogenesis	O
and	O
tissue	O
targeting	O
.	O

Down-regulation	O
of	O
TDT	S-Biological_Molecule
transcription	O
in	O
CD4	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
+	O
)	O
CD8	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
+	O
)	O
thymocytes	O
by	O
Ikaros	S-Biological_Molecule
proteins	O
in	O
direct	O
competition	O
with	O
an	O
Ets	O
activator	O
.	O

Ikaros	S-Biological_Molecule
is	O
a	O
unique	O
regulator	O
of	O
lymphopoiesis	O
that	O
associates	O
with	O
pericentromeric	O
heterochromatin	O
and	O
has	O
been	O
implicated	O
in	O
heritable	O
gene	O
inactivation	O
.	O

Binding	O
and	O
competition	O
experiments	O
demonstrate	O
that	O
Ikaros	S-Biological_Molecule
dimers	O
compete	O
with	O
an	O
Ets	O
activator	O
for	O
occupancy	O
of	O
the	O
lymphocyte-specific	O
TdT	S-Biological_Molecule
promoter	O
.	O

Mutations	O
that	O
selectively	O
disrupt	O
Ikaros	S-Biological_Molecule
binding	O
to	O
an	O
integrated	O
TdT	S-Biological_Molecule
promoter	O
had	O
no	O
effect	O
on	O
promoter	O
function	O
in	O
a	O
CD4	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
+	O
)	O
CD8	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
+	O
)	O
thymocyte	O
line	O
.	O

However	O
,	O
these	O
mutations	O
abolished	O
down-regulation	O
on	O
differentiation	O
,	O
providing	O
evidence	O
that	O
Ikaros	S-Biological_Molecule
plays	O
a	O
direct	O
role	O
in	O
repression	O
.	O

Reduced	O
access	O
to	O
restriction	O
enzyme	O
cleavage	O
suggested	O
that	O
chromatin	O
alterations	O
accompany	O
down-regulation	O
.	O

The	O
Ikaros-dependent	O
down-regulation	O
event	O
and	O
the	O
observed	O
chromatin	O
alterations	O
appear	O
to	O
precede	O
pericentromeric	O
repositioning	O
.	O

Current	O
models	O
propose	O
that	O
the	O
functions	O
of	O
Ikaros	S-Biological_Molecule
should	O
be	O
disrupted	O
by	O
a	O
small	O
isoform	O
that	O
retains	O

and	O
lacks	O
the	O
DNA-binding	O
domain	O
.	O

Surprisingly	O
,	O
in	O
the	O
CD4	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
+	O
)	O
CD8	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
+	O
)	O
thymocyte	O
line	O
,	O
overexpression	O
of	O
a	O
small	O
Ikaros	S-Biological_Molecule
isoform	O
had	O
no	O
effect	O
on	O
differentiation	O
or	O
on	O
the	O
pericentromeric	O
targeting	O
and	O
DNA-binding	O
properties	O
of	O
Ikaros	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

Rather	O
,	O
the	O
small	O
isoform	O
assembled	O
into	O
multimeric	O
complexes	O
with	O
DNA-bound	B-Biological_Molecule
Ikaros	E-Biological_Molecule
at	O
the	O
pericentromeric	O
foci	O
.	O

The	O
capacity	O
for	O
in	O
vivo	O
multimer	O
formation	O
suggests	O
that	O
interactions	O
between	O
Ikaros	S-Biological_Molecule

bound	O
to	O
the	O
TdT	S-Biological_Molecule
promoter	O
and	O

bound	O
to	O
pericentromeric	O
repeat	O
sequences	O
may	O
contribute	O
to	O
the	O
pericentromeric	O
repositioning	O
of	O
the	O
inactive	O
gene	O
.	O

Type	O
I	O
interferons	O
and	O
IL-12	S-Biological_Molecule
:	O
convergence	O
and	O
cross-regulation	O
among	O
mediators	O
of	O
cellular	O
immunity	O
.	O

Therapeutic	O
use	O
of	O
type	B-Biological_Molecule
I	I-Biological_Molecule
IFN	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
IFN-alpha/beta	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
has	O
become	O
common	O
.	O

Many	O
of	O
the	O
diverse	O
diseases	O
targeted	O
are	O
marked	O
by	O
pathogenetic	O
abnormalities	O
in	O
cell-mediated	O
immunity	O
(	O
CMI	O
)	O
,	O
these	O
cellular	O
immune	O
responses	O
either	O
causing	O
injury	O
to	O
the	O
host	S-Species
,	O
lacking	O
sufficient	O
vigor	O
for	O
virus	S-Species
or	O
tumor	O
clearance	O
,	O
or	O
both	O
.	O

In	O
general	O
,	O
therapeutic	O
efficacy	O
is	O
limited	O
.	O

It	O
is	O
thus	O
notable	O
that	O
the	O
pleiotropic	O
effects	O
of	O
type	O
I	O
IFN	O
on	O
CMI	S-Biological_Molecule
remain	O
poorly	O
understood	O
.	O

We	O
characterized	O
the	O
effects	O
of	O
type	B-Biological_Molecule
I	I-Biological_Molecule
IFN	E-Biological_Molecule
on	O
the	O
production	O
of	O
IL-12	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
the	O
central	O
immunoregulatory	O
cytokine	O
of	O
the	O
CD4	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
+	O
)	O
T	O
cell	O
arm	O
of	O
CMI	O
.	O

We	O
show	O
that	O
type	B-Biological_Molecule
I	I-Biological_Molecule
IFN	E-Biological_Molecule
are	O
potent	O
inhibitors	O
of	O
IL-12	S-Biological_Molecule
production	O
by	O
human	S-Species
monocytes/macrophages	O
.	O

The	O
underlying	O

involves	O
transcriptional	O
inhibition	O
of	O
the	O
IL-12p40	S-Biological_Molecule
gene	O
,	O
marked	O
by	O
down-regulation	O
of	O
PU.1	S-Biological_Molecule
binding	O
activity	O
at	O
the	O
upstream	O
Ets	O
site	O
of	O
the	O
IL-12p40	S-Biological_Molecule
promoter	O
.	O

Type	B-Biological_Molecule
I	I-Biological_Molecule
IFN	E-Biological_Molecule
have	O
previously	O
been	O
shown	O
to	O
be	O

to	O
substitute	O
for	O

in	O

production	O
from	O

cells	O
.	O

The	O

of	O

to	O
suppress	O

production	O
while	O

suggests	O
a	O
possible	O

for	O
the	O

of	O
employing	O
these	O
cytokines	O
in	O
diseases	O
involving	O
abnormalities	O
of	O
CMI	O
.	O

Nuclear	O
factor-kappaB	O
suppressive	O
and	O
inhibitor-kappaB	O

effects	O
of	O
troglitazone	S-Chemical_Compound
in	O
obese	O
patients	S-Species
with	O
type	O

:	O
evidence	O
of	O
an	O
antiinflammatory	O
action	O
?	O

It	O
has	O
been	O

that	O

(	O

,	O

of	O

on	O

generation	O
,	O
p47	B-Biological_Molecule
(	I-Biological_Molecule

subunit	E-Biological_Molecule
expression	O
,	O
9-hydroxyoctadecadienoic	B-Chemical_Compound

(	O

,	O

,	O

and	O

in	O

Seven	O
obese	O
patients	S-Species
with	O

(	O

mg/day	O

4	O

were	O

.	O

intake	O
.	O

13-HODE/linoleic	B-Chemical_Compound

and	O

)	O

:	O

and	O

.	O

Invariant	O
chain	O
induces	O
B	O
cell	O
maturation	O
by	O
activating	O
a	O

(	I-Biological_Molecule
II	I-Biological_Molecule
)	I-Biological_Molecule

-dependent	O
transcription	O
program	O
.	O

Early	O
stages	O
of	O

cell	O

in	O

to	O

This	O

is	O

for	O

to	O

Recently	O
,	O

chain	O
(	O

(	I-Biological_Molecule

)	I-Biological_Molecule

.	O

Androgens	S-Chemical_Compound
indirectly	O

thymocyte	O

.	O

Apoptotic	O
processes	O
,	O

(	O

)	O
.	O

Women	S-Species
are	O
,	O

and	O

that	O

(	O

D609	S-Chemical_Compound
inhibits	O

as	O
a	O
potent	O

.	O

Tricyclodecan-9-yl-xanthogenate	S-Chemical_Compound
(	O
D609	S-Chemical_Compound
)	O
has	O
been	O
extensively	O
studied	O
in	O
biological	O
systems	O
and	O
exhibits	O
a	O
variety	O
of	O
biological	O
functions	O

including	O
antiviral	O
,	O
antitumor	O
,	O
and	O
anti-inflammatory	O
activities	O
.	O

Most	O
of	O
these	O
activities	O
have	O
been	O
largely	O
attributed	O
to	O
the	O
inhibitory	O
effect	O
of	O
D609	S-Chemical_Compound
on	O
phosphatidylcholine-specific	B-Biological_Molecule

C	E-Biological_Molecule
.	O

However	O
,	O
as	O
a	O
xanthate	O
derivative	O
,	O
D609	S-Biological_Molecule
is	O
a	O
strong	O

and	O
readily	O
dissociates	O
to	O
xanthate	B-Chemical_Compound
anions	E-Chemical_Compound
and	O
cations	O
of	O
alkali	O
metals	E-Chemical_Compound
in	O
solution	O
.	O

Xanthate	O
anions	E-Chemical_Compound
and	O
protonated	O
xanthic	B-Chemical_Compound
acid	E-Chemical_Compound
contain	O
a	O
free	O
thiol	S-Chemical_Compound
moiety	O
and	O
are	O
highly	O
reductive	O
.	O

This	O
implies	O
that	O
D609	S-Chemical_Compound
and	O
other	O
xanthate	S-Chemical_Compound
derivatives	E-Chemical_Compound
may	O
function	O
as	O
potent	O
antioxidants	S-Chemical_Compound
.	O

Indeed	O
,	O
we	O
found	O
that	O
D609	S-Chemical_Compound
inhibited	O
the	O
Fenton	O
reaction-induced	O
oxidation	O
of	O
dihydrorhodamine	B-Chemical_Compound

in	O
a	O
dose-dependent	O
manner	O
similar	O
to	O
that	O
of	O
pyrrolidinedithiocarbamate	S-Chemical_Compound
,	O
a	O
well	O
known	O
antioxidant	O
.	O

In	O
addition	O
,	O
D609	S-Chemical_Compound
inhibited	O
the	O
formation	O
of	O
the	O
alpha-phenyl-tert-butylnitrone-free	B-Chemical_Compound
radical	E-Chemical_Compound
spin	O

was	O
administered	O
intravenously	O
with	O
or	O
without	O

(	O

AND	O

and	O

CONCLUSION	O
:	O

,	O

of	O
reactive	B-Chemical_Compound
oxygen	I-Chemical_Compound
species	E-Chemical_Compound
and/or	O
nuclear	O
factor-kappaB	O
.	O

Treatment	O
of	O
allergic	O
airway	O
inflammation	O
and	O
hyperresponsiveness	O
by	O
antisense-induced	O
local	O
blockade	O
of	O
GATA-3	S-Biological_Molecule
expression	O
.	O

Recent	O
studies	O
in	O
transgenic	O
mice	S-Species
have	O
revealed	O
that	O
expression	O
of	O
a	O
dominant	O

of	O
the	O

in	O

cells	O
can	O

cell	O
type	O

(	O

)	O

airway	O

in	O
mice	S-Species
.	O

However	O

remains	O

(	I-Biological_Molecule

:	O

were	O

to	O

IFN-gamma	S-Biological_Molecule
may	O

for	O

and	O

in	O

and	O

.	O

Advanced	O

product	O
(	O

)	O

of	O
the	O

within	O

that	O

with	O

(	O

(	O

Antigen-receptor	O

and	O
lipopolysaccharide	S-Chemical_Compound
trigger	O
distinct	O
phosphoinositide	O
3-kinase	E-Biological_Molecule

pathways	O
to	O

activation	O
in	O
primary	O
B	O
cells	O
.	O

The	O
NF-kappaB/Rel	S-Biological_Molecule
transcription	O
factors	O
play	O
an	O
important	O
role	O
in	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
genes	O
involved	O
in	O
B	O
cell	O
development	O
,	O

and	O
function	O
.	O

Nuclear	O
NF-kappaB	S-Biological_Molecule
is	O
induced	O
in	O
B	O
cells	O
by	O
engagement	O
of	O
either	O
the	O
BCR	S-Biological_Molecule
or	O
CD40	S-Biological_Molecule
or	O
by	O
stimulation	O
with	O
lipopolysaccharide	S-Chemical_Compound
(	O
LPS	S-Chemical_Compound
)	O
.	O

Despite	O
the	O
importance	O
of	O
NF-kappaB	S-Biological_Molecule
to	O
B	O
cell	O
function	O
,	O
little	O
is	O
known	O
about	O
the	O
signaling	O
pathways	O
leading	O
to	O
NF-kappaB	S-Biological_Molecule
activation	O
.	O

In	O
this	O
report	O
we	O
address	O
the	O
role	O
of	O
phosphoinositide	B-Biological_Molecule
3'-kinase	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
PI	O
3-kinase	E-Biological_Molecule
)	O
in	O
BCR	S-Biological_Molecule
-	O
and	O
LPS-induced	O
NF-kappaB	S-Biological_Molecule
activation	O
using	O
populations	O
of	O
primary	O
murine	S-Species
resting	O
B	O
cells	O
.	O

Using	O
the	O
specific	O
pharmacological	O
inhibitors	O
of	O
PI	B-Biological_Molecule
3-kinase	E-Biological_Molecule
,	O
Wortmannin	S-Chemical_Compound
and	O
LY294002	S-Chemical_Compound
,	O
we	O
demonstrate	O
that	O
PI	B-Biological_Molecule
3-kinase	E-Biological_Molecule
activity	O
is	O
vital	O
for	O
BCR	S-Biological_Molecule
-induced	O
NF-kappaB	O
DNA-binding	O
activity	O
.	O

Furthermore	O
,	O
we	O
show	O
that	O
this	O
is	O
achieved	O
via	O
protein	O
kinase	O
C	O
-dependent	O
degradation	O
of	O
IkappaBalpha	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

Similar	O
analyses	O
reveal	O
that	O
PI	B-Biological_Molecule
3-kinase	E-Biological_Molecule
is	O
also	O
critical	O
in	O
triggering	O
NF-kappaB	O
DNA-binding	O
activity	O
and	O
IkappaBalpha	S-Biological_Molecule
degradation	O
following	O
LPS	S-Chemical_Compound
stimulation	O
.	O

Interestingly	O
,	O
a	O
PKC	S-Biological_Molecule
inhibitor	O
which	O
blocked	O
the	O
BCR	O
-induced	O
IkappaBalpha	S-Biological_Molecule
degradation	O
had	O
no	O
effect	O
on	O
the	O
degradation	O
of	O
IkappaBalpha	S-Biological_Molecule
after	O
LPS	S-Chemical_Compound
stimulation	O
.	O

Taken	O
together	O
,	O
our	O
results	O
indicate	O
the	O
involvement	O
of	O
PI	B-Biological_Molecule
3-kinase	E-Biological_Molecule
in	O
at	O
least	O
two	O
distinct	O
signaling	O
pathways	O

to	O

of	O
NF-kappaB	S-Biological_Molecule
in	O
B	O
cells	O
.	O

Tetramer-guided	O
epitope	O
mapping	O
:	O
rapid	O
identification	O
and	O
characterization	O
of	O
immunodominant	O
CD4+	S-Biological_Molecule
T	O
cell	O
epitopes	O
from	O
complex	O
antigens	O
.	O

T	O
cell	O
responses	O
to	O
Ags	S-Biological_Molecule
involve	O
recognition	O
of	O
selected	O
peptide	O
epitopes	O
contained	O
within	O
the	O
antigenic	O
protein	O
.	O

In	O
this	O
report	O
,	O
we	O
describe	O
a	O
new	O
approach	O
for	O
direct	O
identification	O
of	O

T	O
cell	O
epitopes	O
of	O
complex	O
Ags	S-Biological_Molecule
that	O
uses	O
human	S-Species
class	B-Biological_Molecule
II	I-Biological_Molecule

to	O
identify	O
reactive	O
cells	O
.	O

With	O
a	O

of	O
60	O

the	O
entire	O

of	O
the	O
VP16	S-Biological_Molecule
protein	O

a	O

for	O
HSV-2	S-Species

we	O
generated	O
a	O
panel	O
of	O
class	O
II	O

with	O

to	O

of	O

infected	O

.	O

With	O
this	O

we	O
identified	O
four	O
new	O
DRA1*0101/DRB1*0401-	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
two	O

By	O

to	O

a	O

to	O
these	O

Although	O

and	O

high	O

of	O
individual	O

within	O
common	O

.	O

This	O
rapid	O
approach	O
to	O
detecting	O
CD4+	S-Biological_Molecule
T	O
cell	O
epitopes	O
from	O
complex	O
Ags	S-Biological_Molecule
can	O

to	O
any	O

that	O

a	O

.	O

Localized	O
pancreatic	O

activation	O
and	O

response	O
in	O
taurocholate-induced	O
pancreatitis	O
.	O

Transcription	O
factor	O

(	O

)	O
is	O

(	O

CD45	B-Biological_Molecule
tyrosine	I-Biological_Molecule
phosphatase	E-Biological_Molecule
controls	O
common	O
gamma-chain	S-Biological_Molecule
cytokine	O
-mediated	O
STAT	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
extracellular	O
signal-related	I-Biological_Molecule
kinase	O
phosphorylation	O
in	O

human	S-Species
lymphoblasts	O

inhibition	O
of	O

without	O
induction	O
of	O

.	O

The	O

of	O
this	O

To	O

generated	O

after	O

In	O

with	O

mAb	O

,	O
but	O
not	O
control	O

mAbs	O

significant	O

of	O
proliferation	O
.	O

Interestingly	O

the	O

mAb	O

,	O
which	O
is	O
most	O

.	O

of	O

had	O
no	O

epitopes	O
(	O

are	O

activated	O
human	S-Species
lymphoblasts	O
.	O

Pax5	S-Biological_Molecule
determines	O
the	O
identity	O
of	O
B	O
cells	O
from	O
the	O
beginning	O
to	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
B-lymphopoiesis	S-Species
.	O

Despite	O
being	O
one	O
of	O
the	O
most	O
intensively	O
studied	O
cell	O
types	O
,	O
the	O
molecular	O
basis	O
of	O
B	O
cell	O
specification	O
is	O
largely	O
unknown	O
.	O

The	O
Pax5	S-Biological_Molecule
gene	O
encoding	O
the	O
transcription	O
factor	O
BSAP	S-Biological_Molecule
is	O
required	O
for	O
progression	O
of	O
B-lymphopoiesis	S-Species
beyond	O
the	O
pro-B	S-Biological_Molecule
cell	O
stage	O
.	O

Pax5-deficient	O
pro-B	O
cells	O
are	O
,	O
however	O
,	O
not	O
yet	O
committed	O
to	O
the	O

lineage	O

but	O
instead	O
have	O
a	O
broad	O

developmental	O
potential	O
.	O

Pax5	S-Biological_Molecule
appears	O
to	O
mediate	O
B-lineage	S-Biological_Molecule
commitment	O
by	O
repressing	O
the	O
transcription	O
of	O
non-B-lymphoid	O
genes	O
and	O
by	O
simultaneously	O
activating	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
B-lineage-specific	O
genes	O
.	O

Pax5	S-Biological_Molecule
thus	O
functions	O
both	O
as	O
a	O
transcriptional	O
repressor	O
and	O
activator	O
,	O
depending	O
on	O
its	O
interactions	O
with	O
corepressors	O
of	O
the	O
Groucho	O
protein	O
family	O
or	O
with	O
positive	O
regulators	O
such	O
as	O
the	O
TATA-binding	S-Biological_Molecule
protein	O
.	O

Once	O
committed	O
to	O
the	O
B-lineage	O
,	O
B	O
cells	O
require	O
Pax5	S-Biological_Molecule
function	O
to	O
maintain	O
their	O
B-lymphoid	O
identity	O
throughout	O
B	O
cell	O
development	O

Partners	O
in	O
transcription	O
:	O
NFAT	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
AP-1	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

Combinatorial	O
regulation	O
is	O
a	O
powerful	O
mechanism	O
that	O
enables	O
tight	O
control	O
of	O
gene	O
expression	O
,	O
via	O
integration	O
of	O
multiple	O
signaling	O
pathways	O
that	O
induce	O
different	O
transcription	O
factors	O
required	O
for	O
enhanceosome	O
assembly	O
.	O

The	O
four	O
calcium-regulated	O
transcription	O
factors	O
of	O
the	O
NFAT	O
family	O
act	O
synergistically	O
with	O
AP-1	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
Fos/Jun	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
proteins	O
on	O
composite	O
DNA	O
elements	O
which	O
contain	O
adjacent	O
NFAT	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O

binding	O
sites	O
,	O
where	O
they	O
form	O
highly	O
stable	O

to	O
regulate	O

of	O

inducible	O
genes	O
.	O

Concomitant	O

of	O
NFAT	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O

requires	O
concerted	O
activation	O
of	O
two	O

signaling	O
pathways	O
:	O
calcium/calcineurin	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O

and	O
activation	O
;	O
and	O
protein	O
kinase	O
C	O
(	O
PKC	O
)	O
/Ras	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
which	O
promotes	O
the	O
synthesis	O
,	O
phosphorylation	O
and	O
activation	O
of	O
members	O
of	O
the	O
Fos	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O

families	O
of	O
transcription	O
factors	O
.	O

A	O
fifth	O

of	O

NFAT	S-Biological_Molecule
family	O

,	O
controls	O

to	O

that	O
requires	O

and	O

of	O

with	O
AP-1	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

Pharmacological	O
interference	O
with	O
theNFAT	S-Biological_Molecule
:	O
AP-1	S-Biological_Molecule
interaction	O
may	O
be	O

in	O

of	O
the	O
immune	O
response	O
.	O

Balanced	O

of	O

and	O

is	O

to	O

,	O
but	O

of	O

:	O

interactions	O
in	O

and	O

processes	O
remains	O
to	O
be	O
understood	O
.	O

Cytokine	O
production	O
by	O
Vgamma	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
+	O
)	O
-T-cell	O
subsets	O
is	O
an	O
important	O
factor	O
determining	O
CD4	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
+	O
)	O

phenotype	O
and	O
susceptibility	O
of	O

mice	O
to	O
coxsackievirus	O

myocarditis	O
.	O

Two	O
coxsackievirus	O
B3	O
(	O
CVB3	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
variants	O
(	O
H3	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
H310A1	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
differ	O
by	O
a	O
single	O

acid	O

in	O
the	O

capsid	O
protein	O
.	O

H3	S-Biological_Molecule
induces	O
severe	O
myocarditis	O
in	O
BALB/c	B-Species
mice	E-Species
,	O
but	O
H310A1	S-Biological_Molecule
is	O
amyocarditic	O
.	O

Infection	O
with	O
H3	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
but	O
not	O

,	O

activates	O

cells	O

which	O
are	O
strongly	O
positive	O
for	O

interferon	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
IFN-gamma	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O

Plasmin	S-Biological_Molecule

of	O

and	O
tissue	B-Biological_Molecule

in	O

Plasmin	O

and	O
inflammation	O
.	O

(	O

2001	O
;	O

:	O

)	O

STAT3	S-Biological_Molecule
is	O
constitutively	O
active	O
in	O
some	O
patients	S-Species
with	O
Polycythemia	B-Species
rubra	E-Species
vera	O
.	O

OBJECTIVE	O
:	O
Polycythemia	O
vera	O
is	O
a	O
clonal	O
stem	O
cell	O
disorder	O
characterized	O
by	O
hyperproliferation	O
of	O
the	O
erythroid	O
,	O
myeloid	O
,	O
and	O
megakaryocytic	O
lineages	O
.	O

While	O
it	O
has	O
been	O
shown	O
that	O
progenitor	O
cells	O
of	O
P.	O
vera	O
patients	S-Species
are	O
hypersensitive	O
to	O
several	O
growth	O

including	O
erythropoietin	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
insulin-like	O
growth	O
factor-1	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
thrombopoietin	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
interleukin-3	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
and	O

factor	E-Biological_Molecule
,	O

of	O
this	O
disease	O
remains	O
unknown	O
.	O

Growth	O
factor	O

could	O
be	O
mediated	O
by	O
changes	O
in	O
signal	O
transduction	O
pathways	O
.	O

We	O
therefore	O
investigated	O
a	O
common	O
downstream	O

of	O

,	O
the	O
signal	O
transducers	O
and	O

of	O

(	O

)	O
.	O

A	O
constitutive	O

of	O
STAT	O
factors	O
could	O
explain	O
the	O
increased	O

of	O

vera	O
cells	O
even	O
in	O

of	O
growth	O
factor	O
stimulation	O
.	O

METHODS	O
:	O
Peripheral	O

from	O
patients	S-Species
with	O

vera	O
and	O
from	O
healthy	O

were	O
assayed	O
for	O
STAT1	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O

,	O
and	O

binding	O
by	O
electrophoretic	O
mobility	O
shift	O
assay	O
.	O

RESULTS	O
:	O
Four	O
of	O
14	O

vera	O
patients	S-Species
analyzed	O
showed	O
constitutive	O

in	O
unstimulated	O

while	O

did	O
.	O

None	O
of	O
the	O

or	O

activity	O

Western	O

that	O
,	O
in	O
the	O

patients	S-Species
,	O
STAT3	S-Biological_Molecule
is	O
constitutively	O

on	O

705	E-Chemical_Compound
,	O

and	O

.	O

It	O
was	O

in	O
a	O

diagnosed	O
patient	S-Species
and	O

CONCLUSION	O
:	O
Our	O
data	O
suggest	O
that	O

and	O

of	O
STAT3	S-Biological_Molecule
is	O
not	O
a	O

by	O

of	O

represents	O
a	O
primary	O
molecular	O

.	O

Constitutively	O
active	O
STAT3	S-Biological_Molecule
may	O
contribute	O
to	O
the	O
growth	O
factor	O
hypersensitivity	O
of	O
P.	O
vera	O
cells	O
.	O

of	O

sites	O
for	O
Bruton	S-Chemical_Compound
's	O
tyrosine	O
kinase	O
within	O
the	O

regulator	O

.	O

Bruton	B-Biological_Molecule
's	I-Biological_Molecule
tyrosine	I-Biological_Molecule
kinase	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
Btk	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
,	O
a	O
member	O
of	O
the	O

of	O

is	O
essential	O

and	O

.	O

BAP/TFII-I	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
a	O

for	O

in	O
vitro	O
and	O
is	O

on	O

In	O
an	O

of	O

These	O

Tyr248	S-Chemical_Compound
,	O

and	O

may	O

.	O

of	O
interferon	S-Biological_Molecule

protein	E-Biological_Molecule

Mice	S-Species
deficient	O
in	O
the	O
interferon	B-Biological_Molecule
consensus	I-Biological_Molecule
sequence	I-Biological_Molecule
binding	I-Biological_Molecule

(	O
ICSBP	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O

a	O

resembling	O
chronic	O

(	O

)	O

oncoprotein	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

Interferon-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O

)	O
induces	O

expression	O
and	O
is	O

for	O

This	O

whether	O

;	O
results	O

that	O

cells	O
generated	O
a	O
protective	O
CD8	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
+	O
)	O

against	O

a	O

.	O

ICSBP	S-Biological_Molecule
expression	O
represents	O
a	O
novel	O

Epstein-Barr	B-Species
virus	E-Species
(	O
EBV	S-Species
)	O
is	O
a	O
ubiquitous	O
and	O
highly	O
immunotropic	O
gamma	O
herpesvirus	O
that	O
infects	O
more	O
than	O
90	O
%	O
of	O
humans	S-Species
worldwide	O
.	O

Its	O
pathogenicity	O
leads	O
to	O
a	O
number	O
of	O
diseases	O
including	O
tumors	O
that	O
result	O
from	O
EBV	S-Species
's	O
ability	O
to	O
readily	O
transform	O
B-lymphocytes	O
and	O
,	O
to	O
a	O
lesser	O
extent	O
,	O
epithelial	O
cells	O
.	O

EBV	S-Species
utilizes	O
CD21/CR2	S-Biological_Molecule
as	O
its	O
receptor	O
on	O

cells	O
to	O
initiate	O
the	O
infection	O
process	O
.	O

EBV	S-Species
binds	O
to	O
CR2	S-Biological_Molecule
through	O
its	O
major	O
envelope	O
glycoprotein-350	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
gp350	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O

is	O
also	O
a	O

.	O

that	O

(	O

of	O

12	O
hours	O
for	O
EBV	S-Species

6	O

for	O
rgp350	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O

:	O

was	O

the	O
brain	O
and	O
the	O
clinical	O
severity	O
of	O
EAE	O
opens	O
a	O
novel	O
therapeutic	O
approach	O
for	O
prevention	O
of	O
autoimmune	O
diseases	O
.	O

In	O
vivo	O
detection	O
of	O
intracellular	O
signaling	O
pathways	O
in	O
developing	O
thymocytes	O
.	O

Information	O
regarding	O
the	O
intracellular	O
signaling	O
processes	O
that	O
occur	O
during	O
the	O
development	O
of	O
T	O
cells	O
has	O
largely	O
been	O
obtained	O
with	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
transgenic	O
mouse	S-Species
models	O
,	O
which	O
although	O
providing	O
invaluable	O
information	O
are	O
time	O
consuming	O
and	O
costly	O
.	O

To	O
this	O
end	O
,	O
we	O
have	O
developed	O
a	O
novel	O
system	O
that	O
facilitates	O
the	O
in	O
vivo	O
analysis	O
of	O
signal	O
transduction	O
pathways	O
during	O
T-lymphocyte	O
development	O
.	O

This	O
approach	O
uses	O
reporter-plasmids	S-Chemical_Compound
for	O
the	O
detection	O
of	O
intracellular	O
signals	O
mediated	O
by	O
the	O
mitogen-activated	O
protein	O
kinase	O
or	O
cyclic	O

protein	O
kinase	O
.	O

Reporter-plasmids	O
are	O
transfected	O
into	O
thymocytes	O
in	O
fetal	O
thymic	O
organ	O
culture	O
by	O
accelerated	O
DNA/particle	S-Biological_Molecule
bombardment	O
(	O
gene	O
gun	O
)	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
activation	O
of	O
a	O
signaling	O
pathway	O
is	O
determined	O
in	O
the	O
form	O
of	O
a	O
standard	O
luciferase	S-Biological_Molecule
assay	O
.	O

Importantly	O
,	O
this	O
powerful	O
technique	O
preserves	O
the	O
structural	O
integrity	O
of	O
the	O
thymus	O
,	O
and	O
will	O
provide	O
an	O
invaluable	O
tool	O
to	O
study	O
how	O
thymocytes	O
respond	O
to	O
normal	O
environmental	O
stimuli	O
encountered	O
during	O
differentiation	O
within	O
the	O
thymic	O
milieu	O
.	O

Thus	O
,	O
this	O
method	O
allows	O
for	O
the	O
monitoring	O
of	O
signals	O
that	O
occur	O
in	O
a	O
biological	O

such	O
as	O
during	O
differentiation	O

and	O
within	O
the	O
natural	O
environment	O
of	O
differentiating	O
cells	O
.	O

Core-binding	B-Biological_Molecule
factor	I-Biological_Molecule

(	O

)	O

CD28	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
T	O
cell	O
co-stimulation	O
.	O

Over	O
the	O
last	O

concept	O
of	O
T	O
cell	O
co-stimulation	O
has	O
emerged	O
to	O
take	O
a	O
central	O

in	O
the	O
process	O
of	O
T	O

activation	O
.	O

However	O

is	O

.	O

In	O

of	O

.	O

.	O

Hyperhomocysteinemia	S-Species
has	O

for	O

.	O

.	O

Monocyte	B-Biological_Molecule
chemoattractant	I-Biological_Molecule

(	O

)	O

pathways	O
are	O
induced	O
in	O
DP	S-Chemical_Compound
thymocytes	O
as	O

to	O
mature	O

cells	O
upon	O

with	O
antigen	O
.	O

mice	S-Species
expressing	O

a	O

with	O

or	O

a	O

of	O

of	O

in	O

were	O

.	O

Cell	O

and	O

(	O
2000	O
)	O
7	O
,	O
1253	O
-	O

.	O

CD2	S-Biological_Molecule
stimulation	O
leads	O
to	O
the	O
delayed	O
and	O

activation	O
of	O
STAT1	S-Biological_Molecule
in	O
T	O
cells	O
but	O
not	O
NK	O
cells	O
.	O

OBJECTIVE	O
:	O
T	O
lymphocytes	O
can	O
be	O
activated	O
by	O
soluble	O
factors	O
such	O
as	O
cytokines	O
or	O
through	O
direct	O
cell-cell	O
interactions	O
.	O

Although	O
cytokine	O
receptors	O
are	O
known	O
to	O
signal	O
through	O
STAT	O
family	O
transcription	O
factors	O
,	O
the	O
mechanisms	O
by	O
which	O
other	O
cell-surface	O
molecules	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
CD2	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
transduce	S-Biological_Molecule
signals	O
is	O
unclear	O
.	O

The	O
goal	O
of	O
this	O
study	O
was	O
to	O
determine	O
whether	O
stimulation	O
of	O
T	O
cells	O
through	O
CD2	S-Biological_Molecule
recapitulates	O
aspects	O
of	O
cytokine	O
-induced	O
T-cell	O
activation	O
by	O
use	O
of	O
STAT	S-Biological_Molecule
transcription	O
factors	O
.	O

MATERIALS	O
AND	O
METHODS	O
:	O
T	O
cells	O
were	O
treated	O
with	O
anti-CD2	O
antibodies	O
or	O
cells	O
bearing	O
the	O
natural	O
CD2	S-Biological_Molecule
ligand	E-Biological_Molecule
CD58	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
after	O
which	O
signaling	O
through	O
STAT	O
transcription	O
factors	O
was	O
assessed	O
.	O

RESULTS	O
:	O
Stimulation	O
of	O
CD2	S-Biological_Molecule
on	O
primary	O
T	O
lymphocytes	O
leads	O
to	O
the	O
tyrosine	S-Chemical_Compound
phosphorylation	O
,	O
nuclear	O
translocation	O
,	O
and	O
DNA	O
binding	O
of	O
STAT1	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

In	O
contrast	O
to	O
stimulation	O
by	O
cytokines	O
,	O
the	O
activation	O
of	O
STAT1	S-Biological_Molecule
in	O
response	O
to	O
CD2	S-Biological_Molecule
ligation	O
is	O
delayed	O
and	O
does	O
not	O
involve	O
Jak	O
kinases	O
.	O

Furthermore	O
,	O
while	O
STAT	S-Biological_Molecule
phosphorylation	O
induced	O
by	O
cytokines	O
is	O
generally	O
transient	O
,	O
STAT1	S-Biological_Molecule
phosphorylation	O
following	O
CD2	S-Biological_Molecule
stimulation	O
persists	O
for	O
a	O
period	O
of	O
days	O
.	O

Transcription	O
of	O
key	O
target	O
genes	O
such	O
as	O
IRF1	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
c-fos	S-Biological_Molecule
proceeds	O
with	O
delayed	O
kinetics	O
following	O
CD2	S-Biological_Molecule
stimulation	O
,	O
suggesting	O
that	O
this	O
unique	O
pattern	O
of	O
STAT	S-Biological_Molecule
activation	O
may	O
lead	O
to	O
a	O
distinct	O
cellular	O
response	O
following	O
CD2	S-Biological_Molecule
ligation	O
.	O

This	O
pathway	O
appears	O
to	O
be	O
restricted	O
to	O
T	O
cells	O
,	O
as	O
stimulation	O
of	O
CD2	S-Biological_Molecule
on	O
NK	O
cells	O
does	O
not	O
lead	O
to	O
STAT1	S-Biological_Molecule
activation	O
.	O

CONCLUSION	O
:	O
Stimulation	O
of	O
T	O
cells	O
through	O
cell-surface	O
molecules	O
such	O
as	O
CD2	S-Biological_Molecule
involves	O
activation	O
of	O
STAT	O
transcription	O
factors	O
,	O
thus	O
recapitulating	O
elements	O
of	O
cytokine	O
signaling	O
.	O

NFATc1	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
NFATc2	S-Biological_Molecule
together	O
control	O
both	O
T	O
and	O
B	O
cell	O
activation	O
and	O
differentiation	O
.	O

NFAT	S-Biological_Molecule
transcription	O
factors	O
play	O
critical	O
roles	O
in	O
gene	O
transcription	O
during	O
immune	O
responses	O
.	O

To	O
investigate	O
further	O
the	O
two	O
most	O
prominent	O
NFAT	O
family	O
members	O
,	O
NFATc1	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
NFATc2	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
we	O
generated	O
mice	S-Species
bearing	O
lymphoid	O
systems	O
devoid	O
of	O
both	O
.	O

Doubly	O
deficient	O
T	O
cells	O
displayed	O
cell	O
surface	O
markers	O
of	O
activation	O
yet	O
were	O
significantly	O
deficient	O
in	O
the	O
development	O
of	O
multiple	O
effector	O
functions	O
,	O
including	O
Th	O
cytokine	O
production	O
,	O
surface	O
effector	O
molecule	O
expression	O
,	O
and	O
cytolytic	O
activity	O
.	O

Nevertheless	O
,	O
doubly	O
deficient	O
B	O
cells	O
were	O
hyperactivated	O
,	O
as	O
evidenced	O
by	O
extremely	O
elevated	O
serum	O
IgG1	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
IgE	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
plasma	O
cell	O
expansion	O
and	O
infiltration	O
of	O
end	O
organs	O
.	O

Thus	O
,	O
in	O
T	O
cells	O
,	O
NFATc1	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
NFATc2	S-Biological_Molecule
are	O
dispensable	O
for	O
inflammatory	O
reactivity	O
but	O
are	O
required	O
for	O
effector	O
differentiation	O
,	O
while	O
in	O
B	O
cells	O
,	O
NFATs	S-Biological_Molecule
regulate	O
both	O
normal	O
homeostasis	O
and	O
differentiation	O
.	O

Epstein-barr	B-Species
virus	E-Species
immediate-early	O
protein	O
BZLF1	S-Biological_Molecule
is	O
SUMO-1	S-Biological_Molecule
modified	O
and	O
disrupts	O
promyelocytic	O
leukemia	O
bodies	O
.	O

Although	O
the	O
immediate-early	O
proteins	O
of	O
both	O
herpes	B-Species
simplex	I-Species
virus	E-Species
(	O
HSV	S-Species
)	O
and	O
cytomegalovirus	S-Species
(	O
CMV	S-Species
)	O
are	O
known	O
to	O
modify	O
promyelocytic	O
leukemia	O
(	O
PML	O
)	O
(	O
ND10	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
bodies	O
in	O
the	O
nucleus	O
of	O
the	O
host	S-Species
cell	O
,	O
it	O
has	O
been	O
unclear	O
whether	O
lytic	O
infection	O
with	O
gamma	B-Species
herpesviruses	O
induces	O
a	O
similar	O
effect	O
.	O

The	O
PML	S-Biological_Molecule
protein	O
is	O
induced	O
by	O
interferon	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
involved	O
in	O
major	O
histocompatibility	O
complex	O
class	O

and	O
necessary	O
for	O
certain	O
types	O
of	O

.	O

Therefore	O
,	O
it	O
is	O
likely	O
that	O

bodies	O
function	O
in	O
an	O
antiviral	O
capacity	O
.	O

SUMO-1	S-Biological_Molecule
modification	O
of	O
PML	S-Biological_Molecule
is	O
known	O
to	O
be	O
required	O
for	O
the	O

of	O
PML	S-Biological_Molecule
bodies	O
.	O

To	O
examine	O
whether	O

(	O

)	O

expressed	O

immediate-early	O
genes	O

(	O

(	O

Z	O

and	O

plasma	O

concentrations	O
decreased	O
.	O

that	O

.	O

Tyrosine	S-Chemical_Compound
phosphorylation-dependent	O

of	O

B	E-Biological_Molecule
.	O

BACKGROUND	O
:	O

METHODS	O
:	O
Expression	O
of	O
oestrogen	B-Biological_Molecule

(	O

)	O

(	O

:	O

for	O

(	O

,	O

for	O

for	O

:	O
Mast	O

alone	O

not	O

,	O

,	O

other	O

,	O
express	O

NF	O

Induction	O
of	O

in	O
human	S-Species

by	O

2	O
,	O

acid	E-Chemical_Compound
.	O

Dimethylammonium	B-Chemical_Compound
salt	E-Chemical_Compound
of	O
2	B-Chemical_Compound
,	I-Chemical_Compound
4-dichlorophenoxyacetic	I-Chemical_Compound
acid	E-Chemical_Compound
(	O
DMA-2	S-Chemical_Compound
,	O
4-D	O
)	O
is	O
a	O
widely	O
used	O

that	O
is	O
considered	O
moderately	O
toxic	O
.	O

In	O
the	O

found	O
that	O

,	O

is	O

to	O

in	O

of	O
healthy	O

and	O

cells	O
.	O

by	O

,	O
4-D	O
was	O

and	O

dependent	O

independent	O
of	O
Fas	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
TNF	B-Biological_Molecule
receptor	I-Biological_Molecule
1	E-Biological_Molecule
or	O
the	O
aromatic	O
hydrocarbon	O
receptor	O

and	O
involved	O
disruption	O
of	O
the	O
mitochondrial	O
transmembrane	O
potential	O
and	O
activation	O
of	O
caspase-9	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

ZVAD-FMK	S-Chemical_Compound
,	O
a	O
broad-spectrum	O
inhibitor	O
of	O
caspases	O

blocked	O

,	O

apoptosis	O
completely	O
.	O

While	O

of	O

and	O

blocked	O

,	O
4-D-induced	O
apoptosis	O

an	O
inhibitor	O
of	O
caspase-3	O
had	O
a	O

.	O

Unlike	O

caspase	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O

of	O

Our	O
data	O
indicate	O
that	O

,	O

kills	O
human	S-Species
lymphocytes	O

apoptosis	O

on	O

.	O

The	O

of	O

occurs	O
downstream	O
of	O

,	O
and	O

to	O

for	O

all	O

leading	O
to	O
apoptosis	O
.	O

Inhibition	O
of	O
Th1	O
differentiation	O
by	O
IL-6	S-Biological_Molecule
is	O
mediated	O
by	O
SOCS1	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

Interleukin	B-Biological_Molecule
6	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
IL-6	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
is	O
a	O
cytokine	O
produced	O
by	O
immune	O
and	O

plays	O
an	O

the	O

of	O
several	O
cell	O

.	O

Here	O

a	O

of	O

:	O

of	O

cell	O

.	O

While	O

by	O

of	O

of	O

of	I-Biological_Molecule

(	O

with	O

and	I-Biological_Molecule

of	I-Biological_Molecule

(	O
STAT1	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O

by	O

.	O

Previous	O

that	O

(	O

to	O
significantly	O
reduce	O
interleukin	B-Biological_Molecule
(	I-Biological_Molecule

)	I-Biological_Molecule

secretion	O
and	O

:	O

by	O

and	O

on	O

at	O

on	O

in	O

and	O
the	O

of	O

.	O

regulation	O
of	O

.	O

Acute	O

(	O

)	O
is	O
always	O

with	O

)	O

Whether	O

Granulocyte	O
differentiation	O
in	O

from	O

(	O

(	O
-/-	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
)	O
mice	S-Species
was	O
studied	O
and	O

in	O

of	O
agonist-bound	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
ligand-free	S-Biological_Molecule

Our	O

that	O

is	O

for	O

,	O

(	O
-/-	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O

for	O

activation	O

from	O

with	O

Transcription	O
factor	O
AP-4	S-Biological_Molecule
is	O
a	O

for	O

promoter	O

elements	O
.	O

Immunoglobulin	O
(	I-Biological_Molecule
Ig	I-Biological_Molecule
)	E-Biological_Molecule
-kappa	S-Biological_Molecule
promoters	O
from	O
humans	S-Species
and	O
mice	S-Species
share	O
conserved	O
sequences	O
.	O

The	O
octamer	O
element	O
is	O
common	O
to	O

and	O

(	O

the	O

BMS-189453	S-Chemical_Compound

Mechanisms	O
and	O
clinical	O
relevance	O
of	O
nongenomic	O
glucocorticoid	S-Chemical_Compound
actions	O
.	O

Glucocorticoids	S-Chemical_Compound
have	O
profound	O
anti-inflammatory	O
and	O
immunosuppressive	O
actions	O
when	O
used	O
therapeutically	O
.	O

The	O
therapeutic	O
dose	O
is	O
quite	O
variable	O
and	O
depends	O
on	O
the	O
disease	O
,	O
but	O
ranges	O
from	O
very	O
low	O
to	O
extremely	O
high	O
.	O

The	O
rationale	O
for	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
various	O
dosage	O
regimens	O
for	O
specific	O
clinical	O
indications	O
is	O
the	O
existence	O
of	O
three	O
distinct	O
,	O
therapeutically	O
relevant	O
effects	O
:	O
genomic	O
,	O
specific	O
nongenomic	O
and	O
unspecific	O
nongenomic	O
.	O

Genomic	O
effects	O
are	O
mediated	O
by	O
cytosolic	B-Biological_Molecule
receptors	E-Biological_Molecule
that	O
alter	O
expression	O
of	O
specific	O
genes	O
.	O

Specific	O
nongenomic	O
effects	O
occur	O
within	O
a	O
few	O
minutes	O
and	O
are	O
mediated	O
by	O
steroid-selective	O
membrane	O
receptors	O
.	O

Unspecific	O
nongenomic	O
effects	O
occur	O
within	O
seconds	O
,	O
but	O
only	O
at	O
high	O
glucocorticoid	S-Chemical_Compound
dosages	O
,	O
and	O
seem	O
to	O
result	O
from	O
direct	O
interactions	O
with	O
biological	O
membranes	O
.	O

For	O
unspecific	O
nongenomic	O
effects	O
,	O
methylprednisolone	S-Chemical_Compound
and	O
other	O
glucocorticoids	S-Chemical_Compound
have	O
been	O
shown	O
to	O
inhibit	O
cation	O
cycling	O
across	O
the	O
plasma	O
membrane	O
,	O
but	O
to	O
have	O
little	O
effect	O
on	O
protein	O
synthesis	O
.	O

Thus	O
,	O
glucocorticoids	S-Chemical_Compound
could	O
diminish	O
or	O
prevent	O
the	O
acute	O
immune	O
response	O
by	O
interfering	O
with	O
processes	O
such	O
as	O
the	O
rise	O
in	O
intracellular	O
Ca2+	S-Biological_Molecule
concentration	O
.	O

It	O
is	O
proposed	O
that	O
the	O
additional	O

of	O
higher	O

.	O

High	O

(	O

CONCLUSION/INTERPRETATION	S-Biological_Molecule
:	O
These	O
results	O
suggest	O
that	O
high	O
glucose	S-Chemical_Compound
can	O
upregulate	O
intercellular	O
adhesion	O
molecule-1	O
protein	O
and	O
mRNA	O
expression	O
but	O
not	O
vascular	O
adhesion	O
molecule-1	O
expression	O
in	O
mesangial	O
cells	O
and	O
promote	O
leukocyte	O
adhesion	O
through	O
up-regulation	O
of	O
intercellular	O
adhesion	O
molecule-1	O
through	O
osmotic	O
effect	O
,	O
possibly	O
depending	O
on	O
the	O
protein	O
kinase	O
C	O
nuclear	O
factor-kappa	O
B	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
PKC	B-Biological_Molecule
-	I-Biological_Molecule
NF-kappa	I-Biological_Molecule
B	E-Biological_Molecule
)	O
pathway	O
.	O

High	O
glucose	S-Chemical_Compound
itself	O
can	O
also	O
promote	O
mesangial	O
cell	O
proliferation	O
through	O
the	O
PKC-NF-kappa	B-Biological_Molecule
B	E-Biological_Molecule
pathways	O
.	O

We	O
conclude	O
that	O
hyperglycaemia	O
in	O
itself	O
seems	O
to	O
be	O
an	O
important	O
factor	O
in	O
the	O
development	O
of	O
early	O
diabetic	O
nephropathy	O
.	O

Combined	O
corticosteroid/	O
granulocyte	B-Biological_Molecule
colony-stimulating	I-Biological_Molecule
factor	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
G-CSF	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
therapy	O
in	O
the	O
treatment	O
of	O
severe	O
congenital	O
neutropenia	O
unresponsive	O
to	O
G-CSF	S-Biological_Molecule
:	O
Activated	O
glucocorticoid	B-Biological_Molecule
receptors	E-Biological_Molecule
synergize	O
with	O
G-CSF	S-Biological_Molecule
signals	O
.	O

More	O
than	O
90	O
%	O
of	O
patients	S-Species
with	O
severe	O
congenital	O
neutropenia	O
(	O
SCN	O
)	O
respond	O
to	O
granulocyte	B-Biological_Molecule
colony-stimulating	I-Biological_Molecule
factor	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
G-CSF	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
therapy	O
.	O

The	O
basis	O
for	O
the	O
refractory	O
state	O
in	O
the	O
remaining	O
patients	S-Species
is	O
unknown	O
.	O

To	O
address	O
this	O
issue	O

we	O
studied	O
a	O
child	O
with	O
SCN	S-Biological_Molecule
who	O
was	O

to	O

and	O
had	O
a	O
novel	O
point	O
mutation	O
in	O
the	O
extracellular	O
domain	O
of	O
the	O
G-CSF	B-Biological_Molecule
receptor	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
GCSF-R	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
.	O

Marrow	O
stromal	O
support	O
of	O
granulopoiesis	O
was	O
evaluated	O
by	O
plating	O
CD34	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O
+	O
)	O
cells	O
on	O
preformed	O
stromal	O
layers	O
.	O

Nonadherent	O
cells	O
were	O

cell	O

after	O

that	O

of	O

(	O

HUM	O
PATHOL	O
31	E-Biological_Molecule
:	O
1482-1490	O

Human	O

leukemia	I-Biological_Molecule

(	O

)	O

,	O

,	O

,	O
c-Fos	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
and	O

,	O
at	O
the	O

of	O

expression	O
in	O

cells	O
.	O

We	O
examined	O
the	O
activity	O
of	O
Tax	S-Biological_Molecule
in	O
transcription	O
through	O
AP-1-binding	O
sites	O
(	O
AP-1	S-Biological_Molecule
site	O
)	O
in	O
T	O
cells	O
.	O

Transient	O
transfection	O
studies	O
showed	O
that	O
Tax	S-Biological_Molecule
activated	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
a	O
luciferase	S-Biological_Molecule
gene	O
regulated	O
by	O
two	O

of	O
an	O

site	O
in	O
the	O
human	O
Jurkat	O
T-cell	O
line	O
.	O

Tax	S-Biological_Molecule
activates	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
viral	O
and	O
cellular	O
genes	O
through	O
two	O
different	O
enhancers	O
:	O
a	O

(	O

element	O
and	O
a	O
kappaB	O
element	O
.	O

Two	O
Tax	S-Biological_Molecule
mutants	O
differentially	O
activated	O
expression	O
of	O
these	O
two	O
elements	O
.	O

Tax703	S-Biological_Molecule
preferentially	O
activated	O
the	O
kappaB	S-Biological_Molecule
element	O
but	O
not	O
the	O
CRE-like	S-Biological_Molecule
one	O
,	O
whereas	O
TaxM22	S-Biological_Molecule
showed	O
the	O
reverse	O
.	O

In	O
addition	O
,	O
Tax703	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
Tax	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
but	O
not	O
TaxM22	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
converted	O
cell	O
growth	O
of	O
a	O
mouse	S-Species
T-cell	O
line	O
from	O
being	O
interleukin	B-Biological_Molecule
(	I-Biological_Molecule
IL	I-Biological_Molecule
)	I-Biological_Molecule
-2-dependent	E-Biological_Molecule
to	O
being	O
IL-2-independent	O
.	O

Unlike	O
the	O
wild-type	O
Tax	S-Biological_Molecule

Tax703	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
TaxM22	S-Biological_Molecule
only	O

Thus	O

seems	O
to	O

from	O

or	O

.	O

shift	O
assays	O
showed	O
that	O
Tax	S-Biological_Molecule
induced	O
strong	O
binding	O
activity	O
to	O
an	O

site	O
in	O

did	O
not	O

that	O

of	O

by	O
Tax	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

The	O

and	O

Other	O

.	O

Activation	O
of	O
transcription	O
through	O
the	O

in	O

cells	O
by	O
JunD	S-Biological_Molecule

weak	O

c-Jun	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O

,	O

was	O

Thus	O

Human	S-Species

BACKGROUND	O
:	O
Eosinophils	O
are	O
now	O
known	O
to	O
produce	O
a	O
variety	O
of	O
proinflammatory	O
cytokines	O

although	O
the	O
molecular	O
factors	O
that	O
regulate	O
their	O
production	O
are	O
poorly	O
understood	O
.	O

The	O
expression	O
of	O
almost	O
all	O
of	O
the	O
cytokines	O
produced	O
by	O

including	O
the	O

,	O
is	O
now	O
known	O
to	O

at	O

level	O
of	O

by	O
members	O
of	O
the	O
nuclear	O
factor	O
of	O
activated	O
T	O
cells	O
(	O
NFAT	O
)	O
family	O
of	O
transcription	O
factors	O
.	O

OBJECTIVE	O
:	O
We	O
sought	O
to	O
characterize	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
different	O

proteins	O
in	O

and	O

.	O

METHODS	O
:	O
Nuclear	O
and	O
whole	O
cell	O
extracts	O
were	O
obtained	O
from	O
both	O
peripheral	O

and	O
those	O
obtained	O
from	O

of	O

after	O

challenge	O
.	O

NFAT	S-Biological_Molecule
expression	O
was	O
determined	O
by	O
using	O

and	O

blot	O
analysis	O
,	O

and	O

of	O

.	O

RESULTS	O
:	O
Both	O
peripheral	O
blood	O
and	O
bronchoalveolar	O
lavage	O
fluid	O

expressed	O
NFATp	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
NFATc	S-Biological_Molecule
protein	O
.	O

Unlike	O
activated	O
T	O
cells	O

which	O
express	O
multiple	O

isoforms	O

express	O
the	O
approximately	O

.	O

addition	O

were	O

to	O

express	O

mRNA	O
.	O

A	O

with	O
the	O
T	O
(	O
H	O
)	I-Biological_Molecule
2	E-Biological_Molecule
cytokines	O
IL-4	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O

was	O

to	O
induce	O
the	O

of	O

.	O

multiple	O

that	O
can	O
specifically	O
recognize	O
the	O
IL-4	S-Biological_Molecule
promoter	O

site	O
in	O

assays	O

including	O
NFATp	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

CONCLUSION	O
:	O
NFATp	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O

of	O

a	O

in	O
these	O
cells	O
.	O

BLyS	S-Biological_Molecule
BINDS	O
TO	O
B	O
CELLS	O
WITH	O
HIGH	O
AFFINITY	O
AND	O
INDUCES	O
ACTIVATION	O
OF	O
THE	O
TRANSCRIPTION	O
FACTORS	O
NF-kappaB	S-Biological_Molecule
AND	O
ELF-1	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

B	B-Biological_Molecule
lymphocyte	I-Biological_Molecule
stimulator	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
BLyS	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
is	O
a	O
novel	O
member	O
of	O
the	O
TNF	S-Biological_Molecule
family	O
of	O
proteins	O
expressed	O
by	O
myeloid	O
cells	O
as	O
membrane-bound	O
and	O
soluble	O
forms	O
.	O

BLyS	S-Biological_Molecule
was	O
shown	O
to	O
act	O
specifically	O
on	O
B	O
cells	O
,	O
inducing	O
proliferation	O
and	O
immunoglobulin	O
production	O
both	O
in	O
vitro	O
and	O
in	O
vivo	O
.	O

The	O
present	O
study	O
was	O
undertaken	O
to	O
characterize	O
binding	O
of	O
radiolabeled	O
BLyS	S-Biological_Molecule
to	O
its	O
cognate	O
receptor	O
on	O
human	O
B	O
lymphocytes	O
and	O
examine	O
intracellular	O
events	O
initiated	O
by	O
BLyS	S-Biological_Molecule
binding	O
.	O

Similar	O
to	O
other	O
TNF	S-Biological_Molecule
family	O
members	O
,	O
BLyS	S-Biological_Molecule
is	O
present	O
in	O
solution	O
as	O
a	O
homotrimer	O
as	O
determined	O
by	O
gel	O
filtration	O
chromatography	O
and	O
light	O
scattering	O
analysis	O
.	O

BLyS	S-Biological_Molecule
binding	O
to	O
B	O
cells	O
is	O
specific	O
as	O
other	O
TNF	S-Biological_Molecule
family	O
members	O
tested	O
did	O
not	O
compete	O
for	O
(	O
125	O
)	O
I-	S-Biological_Molecule
BLyS	O
binding	O
.	O

Analysis	O
of	O
equilibrium	O
binding	O
of	O
(	O
125	O
)	O
I-labeled	S-Biological_Molecule
BLyS	O
to	O
purified	O
human	S-Species
tonsillar	O
B	O
cells	O
demonstrated	O
saturable	O
binding	O
.	O

Scatchard	O
analysis	O
of	O
the	O
binding	O
data	O
revealed	O
a	O
single	O
class	O
of	O
high-affinity	O
binding	O
on	O
human	O
B	O
cells	O
with	O
approximately	O
2600	O
binding	O
sites	O
per	O
cell	O
and	O
an	O
apparent	O
dissociation	O
constant	O
(	O
K	O
(	O
D	O
)	O
)	O
of	O
about	O
0.1	O
nM	O
.	O

In	O
addition	O
we	O
report	O
that	O
BLyS	S-Biological_Molecule
binding	O
to	O
B	O
cells	O
results	O
in	O
the	O
activation	O
of	O
NF-kappaB	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
the	O
Ets	O
family	O
transcription	O
factor	O
,	O
ELF-1	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
and	O
in	O
the	O
induction	O
of	O
mRNA	O
for	O
Polo-like	B-Biological_Molecule
kinase	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
PLK	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
.	O

2001	O
Academic	O
Press	O
.	O

Design	O
and	O
use	O
of	O
an	O
inducibly	O
activated	O
human	O
immunodeficiency	O
virus	O
type	O
1	O
Nef	S-Biological_Molecule
to	O
study	O
immune	O
modulation	O
.	O

The	O
Nef	S-Biological_Molecule
protein	O
of	O
the	O
human	O
immunodeficiency	O
virus	O
type	O
1	O
(	O
HIV-1	S-Species
)	O
has	O
been	O
shown	O
to	O
enhance	O
the	O
infectivity	O
of	O
virus	S-Species
particles	O
,	O
downmodulate	O
cell	O
surface	O
proteins	O

and	O
associate	O
with	O
many	O
intracellular	O
proteins	O
that	O
are	O
thought	O
to	O
facilitate	O
HIV	S-Species
infection	O
.	O

One	O
of	O
the	O
challenges	O
in	O
defining	O
the	O
molecular	O
events	O
regulated	O
by	O
Nef	S-Biological_Molecule
has	O
been	O
obtaining	O
good	O
expression	O
of	O
Nef	S-Biological_Molecule
protein	O
in	O
T	O
cells	O
.	O

This	O
has	O
been	O
attributed	O
to	O
effects	O
of	O
Nef	S-Biological_Molecule
on	O
cell	O
proliferation	O
and	O
apoptosis	O
.	O

We	O
have	O
designed	O
a	O
Nef	S-Biological_Molecule
protein	O
that	O
is	O
readily	O
expressed	O
in	O
T-cell	O
lines	O
and	O
whose	O
function	O
is	O
inducibly	O
activated	O
.	O

It	O
is	O
composed	O
of	O
a	O
fusion	O
between	O
full-length	O
Nef	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
the	O
estrogen	B-Biological_Molecule
receptor	E-Biological_Molecule
hormone-binding	O
domain	O
(	O
Nef-ER	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
.	O

The	O
Nef-ER	S-Biological_Molecule
is	O
kept	O
in	O
an	O
inactive	O
state	O
due	O
to	O
steric	O
hindrance	O
,	O
and	O
addition	O
of	O
the	O
membrane-permeable	S-Chemical_Compound
drug	O
4-hydroxytamoxifen	S-Chemical_Compound
(	O
4-HT	S-Chemical_Compound
)	O

which	O
binds	O
to	O
the	O
ER	S-Biological_Molecule
domain	O
,	O
leads	O
to	O
inducible	O
activation	O
of	O
Nef-ER	S-Biological_Molecule
within	O
cells	O
.	O

We	O
demonstrate	O
that	O
Nef-ER	S-Biological_Molecule
inducibly	O
associates	O
with	O
the	O
62-kDa	O
Ser/Thr	O
kinase	O
and	O
is	O
localized	O
to	O
specific	O
membrane	O
microdomains	S-Chemical_Compound
(	O
lipid	S-Chemical_Compound
rafts	E-Chemical_Compound
)	O
only	O
after	O
activation	O
.	O

Using	O
this	O
inducible	O
Nef	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
we	O
also	O
compared	O
the	O
specific	O
requirements	O
for	O
CD4	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
HLA-A2	S-Biological_Molecule
downmodulation	O
in	O
a	O

line	O
.	O

Half-maximal	O
downmodulation	O
of	O
cell	O
surface	O
CD4	S-Biological_Molecule
required	O
very	O
little	O
active	O
Nef-ER	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
occurred	O
as	O
early	O
as	O
4	O

of	O

In	O

50	O

of	O

Nef	S-Biological_Molecule

to	O

h	O
and	O
about	O

of	O

.	O

These	O

suggest	O
that	O

may	O

of	O
active	O
Nef	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

The	O

may	O

for	O

pathogenesis	O
and	O
immune	O
evasion	O
.	O

Regulation	O
of	O
chemokine	O
mRNA	O

in	O
a	O
rat	S-Species

of	O
vanadium-induced	O

.	O

Environmental	O

to	O

macrophage	B-Biological_Molecule

Since	O

is	O
a	O

chemoattractant	O
and	O

well	O

.	O

The	O

that	O

To	O

of	O

recently	O

mRNA	O
.	O

p65	S-Biological_Molecule
(	O

)	O
and	O

of	O

of	O

of	O

BACKGROUND/AIM	S-Chemical_Compound
:	O

:	O

:	O

OBJECTIVE	O
:	O
Tumor	B-Biological_Molecule
necrosis	I-Biological_Molecule

MATERIALS	O
AND	O

:	O

acted	O
as	O
an	O
apoptotic	O
agent	O
;	O
in	O
others	O
(	O
HU-3	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
M-07e	O
,	O
TF-1	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
,	O
it	O
had	O
the	O
opposite	O
effect	O
,	O
preventing	O
apoptosis	O
and	O
inducing	O
proliferation	O
.	O

Direct	O
and	O
indirect	O
signaling	O
mechanisms	O
,	O
including	O
NF-kappaB	S-Biological_Molecule
activation	O
and	O
cytokine	O
synthesis	O
,	O
were	O
analyzed	O
.	O

RESULTS	O
:	O
All	O
cell	O
lines	O
tested	O
expressed	O
TNF-	B-Biological_Molecule
alpha	I-Biological_Molecule
receptors	I-Biological_Molecule
I	E-Biological_Molecule
and	O
II	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
responded	O
to	O
TNF-	B-Biological_Molecule
alpha	E-Biological_Molecule
by	O
upregulation	O
of	O
intercellular	O
adhesion	O
molecule-1	O
.	O

In	O
contrast	O
to	O
granulocyte-macrophage	B-Biological_Molecule
colony-stimulating	I-Biological_Molecule
factor	E-Biological_Molecule
(	O
GM-CSF	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
,	O
TNF-	B-Biological_Molecule
alpha	E-Biological_Molecule
did	O
not	O
activate	O
the	O
MAP	O
kinase	O
and	O
p70S6	S-Biological_Molecule
kinase	O
pathways	O
.	O

Nevertheless	O
,	O
inhibitors	O
of	O
these	O
pathways	O
clearly	O
reduced	O
the	O
TNF-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
-induced	O
cell	O
growth	O
,	O
indicating	O
that	O
TNF-	S-Biological_Molecule
alpha-proliferative	O
cells	O
produced	O
a	O
growth	O
factor	O
that	O
induced	O
proliferation	O
upon	O
stimulation	O
of	O
the	O
above	O
pathways	O
.	O

Anti-GM-CSF	S-Biological_Molecule
antibodies	O
inhibited	O
the	O
TNF-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
-induced	O
growth	O
,	O
suggesting	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
an	O
autocrine	O
loop	O
for	O
cell	O
proliferation	O
mediated	O
by	O
GM-CSF	S-Biological_Molecule
.	O

Supporting	O
this	O
notion	O
,	O
TNF-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
-induced	O
upregulation	O
of	O
GM-CSF	S-Biological_Molecule
mRNA	O
levels	O
and	O
protein	O
secretion	O
in	O
the	O
TNF-alpha	S-Biological_Molecule
-proliferative	O
,	O
but	O
not	O
in	O
the	O
TNF-alpha-apoptotic	O
cell	O
lines	O
.	O

CONCLUSION	O
:	O
These	O
data	O
identify	O
GM-CSF	S-Biological_Molecule
synthesis	O
as	O
an	O
early	O
and	O
essential	O
step	O
in	O
TNF-	S-Biological_Molecule
alpha-induced	O
proliferation	O
.	O

We	O
show	O
for	O
the	O
first	O
time	O
that	O
TNF-alpha-treated	O
cell	O
lines	O
producing	O
no	O
or	O
only	O
minimal	O
amounts	O
of	O
GM-CSF	S-Biological_Molecule
demonstrate	O
an	O
apoptotic	O
phenotype	O
,	O
while	O
cell	O
lines	O
with	O
high	O
GM-CSF	S-Biological_Molecule
expression	O
rates	O
can	O
escape	O
from	O
growth	O
arrest	O
or	O
even	O
apoptosis	O
.	O

In	O
this	O
context	O
,	O
we	O
discuss	O
arguments	O
pointing	O
at	O

as	O
regulator	O
of	O

as	O

for	O

of	O

apoptosis	O

of	O

for	O

.	O

.	O

SRE	S-Biological_Molecule
was	O

.	O

A	O

of	O

and	O

is	O

Tumor	B-Biological_Molecule

(	O

Nitric	B-Chemical_Compound

The	O

factor	O

(	O

.	O

We	O
have	O

that	O
a	O

bp	O

.	O

.	O

of	O

,	O

,	O

that	O

B-like	O
binding	O
activity	O
were	O
also	O
reflected	O
in	O
higher	O
constitutive	O
levels	O
of	O
NF-kappa	S-Biological_Molecule

gene	O
expression	O
in	O

cells	O
.	O

Presence	O
of	O
estrogen-binding	O
sites	O
on	O
macrophage-like	O
synoviocytes	O
and	O
CD8+	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
CD29+	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
CD45RO+	S-Biological_Molecule
T	O
lymphocytes	O
in	O
normal	O
and	O
rheumatoid	O
synovium	O
.	O

OBJECTIVE	O
.	O

To	O
study	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
estrogen-binding	O
sites	O
(	O
EBS	O
)	O
in	O
the	O
synovial	O
tissues	O
of	O
male	O
and	O
female	O
patients	S-Species
with	O
rheumatoid	O
arthritis	O
(	O
RA	O
)	O
and	O
in	O
age-	O
and	O
sex-matched	O
healthy	O
controls	O
.	O

METHODS	O
.	O

Both	O
type	O
1	O
(	O
high	O
affinity	O
,	O
low	O
binding	O
capacity	O
)	O
and	O
type	O
2	O
(	O
reduced	O
affinity	O
,	O
higher	O
binding	O
capacity	O
)	O
EBS	O
were	O
investigated	O
in	O
both	O
soluble	O
and	O
nuclear	O
fractions	O
of	O
homogenized	O
synovial	O
tissue	O
samples	O
by	O
a	O
dextran-coated	O
charcoal	O
method	O
.	O

To	O
determine	O
what	O
type	O
of	O
synovial	O
cell	O
was	O
positive	O
for	O
EBS	O
,	O
cryosections	O
of	O
synovial	O
tissues	O
were	O
immunostained	O
with	O
a	O
specific	O
monoclonal	O
anti-estrogen	B-Biological_Molecule
receptor	O
antibody	O
(	O
anti-ER	S-Biological_Molecule
MAb	O
)	O
using	O
both	O
immunofluorescence	O
and	O
immunoperoxidase	S-Biological_Molecule
techniques	O
.	O

Double	O
immunostaining	O
with	O
the	O
anti-ER	S-Biological_Molecule
MAb	O
and	O
with	O
specific	O
MAb	O
to	O
detect	O
different	O
macrophage	O
antigens	O
(	O
Ber-MAC3	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
MAC387	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
CD68	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
and	O
CD8+	S-Biological_Molecule
T	O
cell	O
subsets	O
(	O
CD29+	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
CD45RO+	S-Biological_Molecule
and	O
CD29-	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
CD45RO-	S-Biological_Molecule
)	O
was	O
performed	O
.	O

RESULTS	O
.	O

Higher	O
affinity	O
EBS	O
were	O
found	O
mostly	O
in	O
nuclear	O
cell	O
fractions	O
of	O
either	O
RA	S-Chemical_Compound
or	O
control	O
synovial	O
tissues	O
(	O
28	O
of	O
the	O
33	O
)	O
.	O

These	O
EBS	O
were	O
present	O
to	O
a	O
lesser	O
extent	O
in	O
soluble	O
cell	O
fractions	O
(	O
11	O
of	O
the	O
33	O
)	O
.	O

Immunostaining	O
showed	O
the	O
estrogen	S-Chemical_Compound
receptor-positive	O
cells	O
to	O
be	O
the	O
macrophage-like	O
synoviocytes	O
and	O
the	O
CD8+	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
CD29+	S-Biological_Molecule
T	O
cells	O
both	O
in	O
RA	O
and	O
in	O
control	O
synovial	O
tissues	O
.	O

Higher	O
nuclear	O
content	O
of	O
EBS	S-Biological_Molecule
was	O
consistent	O
with	O
more	O
intense	O
nuclear	O
staining	O
of	O
synoviocytes	O
and	O
T	O
cells	O
.	O

CONCLUSION	O
.	O

It	O
is	O
conceivable	O
that	O
the	O
immunomodulatory	O
activity	O
exerted	O
by	O
estrogens	S-Chemical_Compound
is	O
at	O
least	O
partly	O
mediated	O
through	O
their	O
interaction	O
with	O
EBS	S-Biological_Molecule
that	O
are	O
present	O
on	O
macrophage-like	O
synoviocytes	O
,	O
functioning	O
as	O
antigen-processing	O
and	O
antigen-presenting	O
cells	O
,	O
and	O
on	O
antigen-experienced	O
(	O
memory	O
)	O
CD8+	S-Biological_Molecule
T	O
lymphocytes	O
(	O
CD29+	S-Biological_Molecule
,	O
CD45RO+	S-Biological_Molecule
